Below is a working ‚Äúv1‚Äù playbook you can run end-to-end. It‚Äôs designed to be boring and repeatable.

What you‚Äôll do (high-level)
Launch a fresh RHEL 9 EC2 instance.

Attach/confirm your RHEL subscription (RHSM).

Run this Ansible playbook from your laptop (or your control machine).

Upload/install your theme + plugins (the playbook supports both URL downloads or local zip copies).

You log into WordPress and it looks/works like expected.

RHEL subscription + repos (important)
On RHEL 9, for WordPress plugins/theme to behave normally you usually need:

BaseOS + AppStream

CodeReady Builder (CRB) (for dev/libs dependencies)

EPEL (common WP plugin deps sometimes live here)

PHP packages from RHEL AppStream (or Remi if you truly need a different PHP version‚Äîtry AppStream first)

This playbook will:

register RHSM

enable needed repos

install Nginx/PHP/MariaDB + common extensions

set SELinux contexts for WordPress

configure Nginx ‚Üî PHP-FPM

install WordPress

set sane PHP limits for uploads/image processing

open firewall ports

Ansible playbook (drop-in)
Create a folder like motorcade-rhel-wp/ with these files:

1) inventory.ini
[motorcade]
motorcade1 ansible_host=YOUR_EC2_PUBLIC_IP ansible_user=ec2-user
If your RHEL AMI uses a different SSH user, adjust ansible_user.

2) group_vars/all.yml
# --- RHEL subscription ---
rhsm_username: "YOUR_RHSM_USERNAME"
rhsm_password: "YOUR_RHSM_PASSWORD"
# optional: if you use activation keys instead:
# rhsm_activation_key: "KEY"
# rhsm_org_id: "ORGID"

# --- Site config ---
site_domain: "motorcade.vip"
wp_admin_user: "admin"
wp_admin_password: "CHANGE_ME_STRONG"
wp_admin_email: "you@example.com"
wp_title: "Motorcade Security Solutions"

# --- Paths ---
web_root: "/var/www/motorcade"
wp_path: "{{ web_root }}/public"

# --- Database ---
db_name: "wordpress"
db_user: "wpuser"
db_password: "CHANGE_ME_DB_STRONG"

# --- PHP tuning (uploads / image processing) ---
php_memory_limit: "512M"
php_upload_max_filesize: "128M"
php_post_max_size: "128M"
php_max_execution_time: 300
php_max_input_time: 300

# --- Theme / plugins install (choose one strategy) ---
# Strategy A: local zips copied with Ansible (recommended)
theme_zip_local: "./assets/motorcade-trust-theme.zip"
plugin_zips_local:
  - "./assets/motorcade-content-injector-v1.1.0.zip"

# Strategy B: download from URLs (if you host them somewhere)
# theme_zip_url: "https://example.com/motorcade-trust-theme.zip"
# plugin_zip_urls:
#   - "https://example.com/motorcade-content-injector-v1.1.0.zip"

# Enable HTTPS later (optional)
enable_ssl: false
3) site.yml
---
- name: Motorcade WordPress on RHEL (Nginx + PHP-FPM + MariaDB)
  hosts: motorcade
  become: true

  vars:
    php_packages:
      - php
      - php-fpm
      - php-mysqlnd
      - php-gd
      - php-mbstring
      - php-xml
      - php-json
      - php-opcache
      - php-pecl-zip
      - php-intl
      - php-cli
      - php-curl

    system_packages:
      - nginx
      - mariadb-server
      - unzip
      - tar
      - rsync
      - policycoreutils-python-utils
      - firewalld
      - curl

  tasks:
    - name: Ensure basic packages are installed (dnf)
      ansible.builtin.dnf:
        name: "{{ system_packages }}"
        state: present
        update_cache: true

    # --------------------------
    # RHEL Subscription + Repos
    # --------------------------
    - name: Register with RHSM (username/password)
      community.general.redhat_subscription:
        state: present
        username: "{{ rhsm_username }}"
        password: "{{ rhsm_password }}"
        auto_attach: true
      when: rhsm_username is defined and rhsm_password is defined

    - name: Enable required repos (RHEL 9)
      ansible.builtin.command: >
        subscription-manager repos
        --enable=rhel-9-for-x86_64-baseos-rpms
        --enable=rhel-9-for-x86_64-appstream-rpms
        --enable=codeready-builder-for-rhel-9-x86_64-rpms
      changed_when: false

    - name: Install EPEL release package
      ansible.builtin.dnf:
        name: "https://dl.fedoraproject.org/pub/epel/epel-release-latest-9.noarch.rpm"
        state: present
        disable_gpg_check: true

    # --------------------------
    # Install PHP stack
    # --------------------------
    - name: Install PHP packages
      ansible.builtin.dnf:
        name: "{{ php_packages }}"
        state: present

    - name: Ensure php-fpm is enabled and started
      ansible.builtin.systemd:
        name: php-fpm
        state: started
        enabled: true

    - name: Tune PHP for uploads and image processing
      ansible.builtin.blockinfile:
        path: /etc/php.ini
        marker: "; {mark} ANSIBLE MOTORCADE"
        block: |
          memory_limit = {{ php_memory_limit }}
          upload_max_filesize = {{ php_upload_max_filesize }}
          post_max_size = {{ php_post_max_size }}
          max_execution_time = {{ php_max_execution_time }}
          max_input_time = {{ php_max_input_time }}
      notify: Restart php-fpm

    # --------------------------
    # MariaDB
    # --------------------------
    - name: Enable and start mariadb
      ansible.builtin.systemd:
        name: mariadb
        state: started
        enabled: true

    - name: Install python mysql client libs for Ansible (RHEL)
      ansible.builtin.dnf:
        name: python3-PyMySQL
        state: present

    - name: Create WordPress database
      community.mysql.mysql_db:
        name: "{{ db_name }}"
        state: present
        login_unix_socket: /var/lib/mysql/mysql.sock

    - name: Create WordPress DB user
      community.mysql.mysql_user:
        name: "{{ db_user }}"
        password: "{{ db_password }}"
        priv: "{{ db_name }}.*:ALL"
        host: "localhost"
        state: present
        login_unix_socket: /var/lib/mysql/mysql.sock

    # --------------------------
    # WordPress files
    # --------------------------
    - name: Create web root
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: "{{ wp_path }}"
        state: directory
        owner: nginx
        group: nginx
        mode: "0755"
        recurse: true

    - name: Download WordPress
      ansible.builtin.get_url:
        url: https://wordpress.org/latest.tar.gz
        dest: /tmp/wordpress.tar.gz
        mode: "0644"

    - name: Extract WordPress
      ansible.builtin.unarchive:
        src: /tmp/wordpress.tar.gz
        dest: /tmp
        remote_src: true

    - name: Sync WordPress into docroot (idempotent)
      ansible.builtin.command: >
        rsync -a --delete /tmp/wordpress/ {{ wp_path }}/
      changed_when: false

    - name: Set ownership on WordPress
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: "{{ wp_path }}"
        owner: nginx
        group: nginx
        recurse: true

    - name: Create wp-config.php if missing
      ansible.builtin.copy:
        dest: "{{ wp_path }}/wp-config.php"
        owner: nginx
        group: nginx
        mode: "0640"
        force: false
        content: |
          <?php
          define('DB_NAME', '{{ db_name }}');
          define('DB_USER', '{{ db_user }}');
          define('DB_PASSWORD', '{{ db_password }}');
          define('DB_HOST', 'localhost');
          define('DB_CHARSET', 'utf8mb4');
          define('DB_COLLATE', '');
          $table_prefix = 'wp_';
          define('WP_DEBUG', false);
          if ( !defined('ABSPATH') ) define('ABSPATH', __DIR__ . '/');
          require_once ABSPATH . 'wp-settings.php';

    # --------------------------
    # Nginx configuration
    # --------------------------
    - name: Write nginx server block
      ansible.builtin.copy:
        dest: /etc/nginx/conf.d/motorcade.conf
        mode: "0644"
        content: |
          server {
            listen 80;
            server_name {{ site_domain }} www.{{ site_domain }};

            root {{ wp_path }};
            index index.php index.html;

            client_max_body_size 128m;

            location / {
              try_files $uri $uri/ /index.php?$args;
            }

            location ~ \.php$ {
              include fastcgi_params;
              fastcgi_param SCRIPT_FILENAME $document_root$fastcgi_script_name;
              fastcgi_pass 127.0.0.1:9000;
            }

            location ~* \.(js|css|png|jpg|jpeg|gif|ico|svg|woff2?)$ {
              expires 7d;
              add_header Cache-Control "public";
            }
          }

    - name: Ensure php-fpm listens on 127.0.0.1:9000
      ansible.builtin.replace:
        path: /etc/php-fpm.d/www.conf
        regexp: '^listen\s*=\s*.*$'
        replace: 'listen = 127.0.0.1:9000'
      notify: Restart php-fpm

    - name: Enable and start nginx
      ansible.builtin.systemd:
        name: nginx
        state: started
        enabled: true

    - name: Validate nginx config
      ansible.builtin.command: nginx -t
      changed_when: false

    # --------------------------
    # Firewall + SELinux
    # --------------------------
    - name: Enable and start firewalld
      ansible.builtin.systemd:
        name: firewalld
        state: started
        enabled: true

    - name: Open HTTP/HTTPS ports
      ansible.posix.firewalld:
        service: "{{ item }}"
        permanent: true
        state: enabled
        immediate: true
      loop:
        - http
        - https

    - name: Allow Nginx to connect to PHP-FPM and DB (SELinux boolean)
      ansible.builtin.command: setsebool -P httpd_can_network_connect 1
      changed_when: false

    - name: Set SELinux context for WordPress directory
      ansible.builtin.command: >
        semanage fcontext -a -t httpd_sys_content_t "{{ wp_path }}(/.*)?"
      changed_when: false
      failed_when: false

    - name: Set SELinux context for uploads (writeable)
      ansible.builtin.command: >
        semanage fcontext -a -t httpd_sys_rw_content_t "{{ wp_path }}/wp-content/uploads(/.*)?"
      changed_when: false
      failed_when: false

    - name: Apply SELinux contexts
      ansible.builtin.command: restorecon -Rv "{{ wp_path }}"
      changed_when: false

    # --------------------------
    # Install theme + plugins (local zip strategy)
    # --------------------------
    - name: Create theme/plugins directories
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: "{{ item }}"
        state: directory
        owner: nginx
        group: nginx
        mode: "0755"
      loop:
        - "{{ wp_path }}/wp-content/themes"
        - "{{ wp_path }}/wp-content/plugins"

    - name: Copy theme zip (local)
      ansible.builtin.copy:
        src: "{{ theme_zip_local }}"
        dest: /tmp/theme.zip
        mode: "0644"
      when: theme_zip_local is defined

    - name: Unzip theme into themes directory
      ansible.builtin.unarchive:
        src: /tmp/theme.zip
        dest: "{{ wp_path }}/wp-content/themes"
        remote_src: true
      when: theme_zip_local is defined

    - name: Copy plugin zips (local)
      ansible.builtin.copy:
        src: "{{ item }}"
        dest: "/tmp/{{ item | basename }}"
        mode: "0644"
      loop: "{{ plugin_zips_local | default([]) }}"
      when: plugin_zips_local is defined

    - name: Unzip plugins into plugins directory
      ansible.builtin.unarchive:
        src: "/tmp/{{ item | basename }}"
        dest: "{{ wp_path }}/wp-content/plugins"
        remote_src: true
      loop: "{{ plugin_zips_local | default([]) }}"
      when: plugin_zips_local is defined

    - name: Fix ownership after installs
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: "{{ wp_path }}/wp-content"
        owner: nginx
        group: nginx
        recurse: true

  handlers:
    - name: Restart php-fpm
      ansible.builtin.systemd:
        name: php-fpm
        state: restarted
How to run it
On your control machine (your laptop):

cd motorcade-rhel-wp
mkdir -p assets

# - motorcade-content-injector-v1.1.0.zip

ansible-galaxy collection install community.general community.mysql ansible.posix

ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini site.yml
After playbook completes
Visit: http://motorcade.vip

Finish WP installer (or if you want, we can automate WP-CLI install in playbook v2)

In WP Admin:

Activate Motorcade Trust

Activate your plugins

Upload a hero image again (uploads should work now)

Why this will stop the ‚Äúsame commands over and over‚Äù loop
Because we‚Äôre not ‚Äúdebugging live‚Äù anymore. We‚Äôre:

Pinning a known-good stack

Handling SELinux properly (this is where a lot of RHEL WP setups silently break)

Setting PHP limits explicitly (uploads + processing)

Keeping nginx/php-fpm consistent and idempotent

Two quick questions (answer inline, short)
RHEL 9 correct, yes? (Assuming yes)

Do you want Let‚Äôs Encrypt SSL auto-setup in the playbook too? (yes/no)

If you say ‚Äúyes‚Äù to SSL, I‚Äôll add Certbot + auto-renew + nginx TLS block so https://motorcade.vip is correct on first deploy.

You said:
Yes
ChatGPT said:
I‚Äôm going to update the playbook to include Let‚Äôs Encrypt SSL (certbot), automatic HTTP‚ÜíHTTPS redirect, and a renewal timer, while keeping Nginx+PHP-FPM+WordPress exactly as-is.

Perfect ‚Äî we‚Äôll bake Let‚Äôs Encrypt SSL into the same playbook so the site comes up cleanly on https://motorcade.vip with auto-renew and HTTP‚ÜíHTTPS redirect.

Below are the exact changes you need (drop-in). This assumes:

DNS for motorcade.vip (and optionally www.motorcade.vip) points to this EC2 public IP

Security Group allows 80 + 443

You keep enable_ssl: true

1) Set this in group_vars/all.yml
enable_ssl: true
ssl_email: "you@example.com"
ssl_domains:
  - "motorcade.vip"
  - "www.motorcade.vip"
(You can remove the www entry if you don‚Äôt use it.)

2) Replace your Nginx config section with SSL-aware templates
Update the Nginx config task in site.yml to this:
    - name: Write nginx server block (HTTP only when SSL disabled)
      ansible.builtin.copy:
        dest: /etc/nginx/conf.d/motorcade.conf
        mode: "0644"
        content: |
          server {
            listen 80;
            server_name {{ site_domain }} www.{{ site_domain }};

            root {{ wp_path }};
            index index.php index.html;

            client_max_body_size 128m;

            location / {
              try_files $uri $uri/ /index.php?$args;
            }

            location ~ \.php$ {
              include fastcgi_params;
              fastcgi_param SCRIPT_FILENAME $document_root$fastcgi_script_name;
              fastcgi_pass 127.0.0.1:9000;
            }

            location ~* \.(js|css|png|jpg|jpeg|gif|ico|svg|woff2?)$ {
              expires 7d;
              add_header Cache-Control "public";
            }
          }
      when: not enable_ssl
Add these two Nginx config tasks right after it:
    - name: Write nginx server block for ACME challenge (SSL enabled)
      ansible.builtin.copy:
        dest: /etc/nginx/conf.d/motorcade-acme.conf
        mode: "0644"
        content: |
          server {
            listen 80;
            server_name {% for d in ssl_domains %}{{ d }} {% endfor %};

            # Let‚Äôs Encrypt http-01 challenge
            location ^~ /.well-known/acme-challenge/ {
              root {{ wp_path }};
              default_type "text/plain";
              try_files $uri =404;
            }

            # Temporary: serve site over http until cert exists
            location / {
              root {{ wp_path }};
              index index.php index.html;
              try_files $uri $uri/ /index.php?$args;
            }

            location ~ \.php$ {
              include fastcgi_params;
              fastcgi_param SCRIPT_FILENAME $document_root$fastcgi_script_name;
              fastcgi_pass 127.0.0.1:9000;
            }
          }
      when: enable_ssl

    - name: Remove non-SSL nginx conf if SSL enabled
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: /etc/nginx/conf.d/motorcade.conf
        state: absent
      when: enable_ssl
3) Add Certbot + obtain certificate + switch Nginx to HTTPS
Add these tasks after Nginx is started & validated (right after nginx -t is fine):

    - name: Install certbot
      ansible.builtin.dnf:
        name:
          - certbot
          - python3-certbot-nginx
        state: present
      when: enable_ssl

    - name: Ensure nginx is running before certbot
      ansible.builtin.systemd:
        name: nginx
        state: started
      when: enable_ssl

    - name: Obtain/renew Let's Encrypt certificate (non-interactive)
      ansible.builtin.command: >
        certbot certonly --webroot
        -w {{ wp_path }}
        {% for d in ssl_domains %}-d {{ d }} {% endfor %}
        --email {{ ssl_email }}
        --agree-tos
        --non-interactive
        --keep-until-expiring
      register: certbot_result
      changed_when: "'Congratulations' in certbot_result.stdout or 'successfully received' in certbot_result.stdout"
      failed_when: certbot_result.rc != 0 and ('Certificate not yet due for renewal' not in certbot_result.stdout)
      when: enable_ssl

    - name: Write nginx HTTPS config (after cert exists)
      ansible.builtin.copy:
        dest: /etc/nginx/conf.d/motorcade-ssl.conf
        mode: "0644"
        content: |
          server {
            listen 80;
            server_name {% for d in ssl_domains %}{{ d }} {% endfor %};

            location ^~ /.well-known/acme-challenge/ {
              root {{ wp_path }};
              default_type "text/plain";
              try_files $uri =404;
            }

            location / {
              return 301 https://$host$request_uri;
            }
          }

          server {
            listen 443 ssl http2;
            server_name {% for d in ssl_domains %}{{ d }} {% endfor %};

            ssl_certificate     /etc/letsencrypt/live/{{ ssl_domains[0] }}/fullchain.pem;
            ssl_certificate_key /etc/letsencrypt/live/{{ ssl_domains[0] }}/privkey.pem;

            # reasonable defaults
            ssl_session_cache shared:SSL:10m;
            ssl_session_timeout 10m;

            root {{ wp_path }};
            index index.php index.html;

            client_max_body_size 128m;

            location / {
              try_files $uri $uri/ /index.php?$args;
            }

            location ~ \.php$ {
              include fastcgi_params;
              fastcgi_param SCRIPT_FILENAME $document_root$fastcgi_script_name;
              fastcgi_pass 127.0.0.1:9000;
            }

            location ~* \.(js|css|png|jpg|jpeg|gif|ico|svg|woff2?)$ {
              expires 7d;
              add_header Cache-Control "public";
            }
          }
      when: enable_ssl

    - name: Validate nginx config (after SSL config)
      ansible.builtin.command: nginx -t
      changed_when: false
      when: enable_ssl

    - name: Reload nginx
      ansible.builtin.systemd:
        name: nginx
        state: reloaded
      when: enable_ssl
4) Add automatic renewal (systemd timer)
Add these tasks near the end:

    - name: Enable certbot renewal timer
      ansible.builtin.systemd:
        name: certbot-renew.timer
        enabled: true
        state: started
      when: enable_ssl

    - name: Add deploy hook to reload nginx after renewal
      ansible.builtin.copy:
        dest: /etc/letsencrypt/renewal-hooks/deploy/reload-nginx.sh
        mode: "0755"
        content: |
          #!/usr/bin/env bash
          systemctl reload nginx
      when: enable_ssl
5) Run it
ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini site.yml
Then verify:

https://motorcade.vip loads

`http://motorcade

You said:
Before I launch can we set a swap file up here?
ChatGPT said:
I‚Äôll give you a safe, copy/paste swap setup for RHEL/AL2023, plus how to make it persist and how much to choose for your instance size.

Yes ‚Äî and that‚Äôs a smart move (especially on t3.small (2GB RAM)).

What size swap?
For WordPress + PHP + basic services:

t3.small (2GB RAM): set 2GB swap

If you plan to run heavier stuff (composer, image processing bursts): 4GB is fine too.

I‚Äôll give you the cleanest, most reliable method: swapfile.

Step-by-step: create a swap file (2GB)
Run these commands after you SSH in (swap is configured inside the instance OS, not in the AWS launch wizard).

# 1) Create a 2GB swap file
sudo fallocate -l 2G /swapfile

# If fallocate isn‚Äôt available, use this instead:
# sudo dd if=/dev/zero of=/swapfile bs=1M count=2048 status=progress

# 2) Lock down permissions
sudo chmod 600 /swapfile

# 3) Format it as swap
sudo mkswap /swapfile

# 4) Enable it now
sudo swapon /swapfile

# 5) Verify
swapon --show
free -h
Make it persistent (survives reboot)
echo '/swapfile none swap sw 0 0' | sudo tee -a /etc/fstab
Recommended kernel tuning (prevents ‚Äúswap thrash‚Äù)
This makes Linux prefer RAM and use swap only when needed:

echo 'vm.swappiness=10' | sudo tee /etc/sysctl.d/99-swappiness.conf
sudo sysctl -p /etc/sysctl.d/99-swappiness.conf
Verify:

cat /proc/sys/vm/swappiness
Quick note about ‚Äúbefore I launch‚Äù
You can‚Äôt create swap before launch in the AWS wizard unless you use User Data. If you want, I can also give you a User Data script you paste into ‚ÄúAdvanced details ‚Üí User data‚Äù so swap is created automatically on first boot.

But simplest is:

Launch

SSH in

Run the commands above

If you tell me whether you want 2GB or 4GB, I‚Äôll tailor it (and optionally give you the User Data version).

You said:
Ok so I cant do the swap as a separate drive prior to launch?
ChatGPT said:
Short answer: you can add a separate drive before launch, but you still cannot make it swap until after the OS boots.

Let me break this down cleanly and calmly.

What AWS lets you do before launch
In the Launch Instance ‚Üí Configure storage step you can:

‚úÖ Add additional EBS volumes
‚úÖ Choose size, type (gp3), device name
‚ùå You cannot format or mark it as swap yet

AWS only attaches raw block devices.
Linux configuration always happens after boot.

Your two real options (and which is better)
‚úÖ Option A (RECOMMENDED): Swapfile on root volume
This is what most production servers do today

Why it‚Äôs best for you right now:

Fast (gp3 root is fine)

Simple

No extra AWS cost or complexity

Easy to resize later

Works perfectly for WordPress / PHP / Nginx

You already saw this method ‚Äî and it‚Äôs the correct one.

‚ö†Ô∏è Option B: Separate EBS volume used as swap
This is possible, but more work and not necessary unless:

You want to detach swap later

You‚Äôre doing very heavy workloads

You‚Äôre managing fleets of servers

What the flow looks like:
Before launch

Add a second EBS volume (ex: 4 GB, gp3)

After launch (inside the OS)

lsblk                       # find the new device (e.g. /dev/xvdf)
sudo mkswap /dev/xvdf
sudo swapon /dev/xvdf
echo '/dev/xvdf none swap sw 0 0' | sudo tee -a /etc/fstab
‚ö†Ô∏è Downsides:

More moving parts

Easier to misconfigure

Zero performance benefit for your use case

Very important clarity point (this caused earlier pain)
There is no such thing as a ‚Äúpreconfigured swap disk‚Äù at launch time

AWS:

Attaches disks
Linux:

Decides how they‚Äôre used

That separation is non-negotiable.

What I recommend you do right now
Since you‚Äôre:

On a t3.small

Running WordPress + PHP

Want stability, not complexity

What Ansible actually is (plain English)
Ansible runs on your local machine and:

Connects to your server over SSH

Executes commands for you

In a repeatable, safe, documented way

Think of it as:

‚ÄúA script runner that logs into your EC2 box and types commands exactly the same way every time.‚Äù

No agents. No software needed on the server except Python (already present).

What you need BEFORE running a playbook
You already have most of this.

‚úÖ You already have
EC2 instance running

Public IP: 18.117.220.60

SSH key: motorcade-key.pem

SSH works (ec2-user@...)

‚ùå You still need locally
Ansible installed on your local machine

A single inventory file

A single playbook file

That‚Äôs it.

STEP 1 ‚Äî Install Ansible on your local machine
If your local machine is Linux
Run:

sudo dnf install -y ansible-core
Verify:

ansible --version
You should see version info.

If your local machine is macOS
brew install ansible
If your local machine is Windows
Tell me ‚Äî it‚Äôs different and we‚Äôll do it cleanly.

STEP 2 ‚Äî Create a simple working folder (local)
On your local machine, not the server:

mkdir motorcade-ansible
cd motorcade-ansible
This folder will contain everything.

STEP 3 ‚Äî Create the inventory file (THIS IS IMPORTANT)
Create a file called inventory.ini:

nano inventory.ini
Paste this exactly (replace path if needed):

[motorcade]
motorcade-web-01 ansible_host=18.117.220.60 ansible_user=ec2-user ansible_ssh_private_key_file=~/.ssh/motorcade-key.pem
Save and exit.

This tells Ansible:

Where the server is

Which user to log in as

Which SSH key to use

STEP 4 ‚Äî Test Ansible connection (NO CHANGES MADE)
Run this from inside motorcade-ansible:

ansible motorcade -i inventory.ini -m ping
Expected output:
motorcade-web-01 | SUCCESS => {
    "changed": false,
    "ping": "pong"
}
If this fails, we stop and fix it before proceeding.

STEP 5 ‚Äî What a playbook actually looks like
A playbook is just a YAML file.

Example (DO NOT RUN YET):

- hosts: motorcade
  become: yes
  tasks:
    - name: Ensure system is updated
      dnf:
        name: "*"
        state: latest
Ansible:

Logs in

Runs commands

Stops if anything breaks

Tells you exactly what happened

STEP 6 ‚Äî How you run a playbook (later)
Once we have a playbook:

ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini site.yml
That‚Äôs it.

Step 6 ‚Äî Silence the Python interpreter warning (safe + recommended)

[motorcade]
motorcade-web-01 ansible_host=18.117.220.60 ansible_user=ec2-user ansible_ssh_private_key_file=/home/codeboy/.ssh/motorcade-key.pem ansible_python_interpreter=/usr/bin/python3

Step 7 ‚Äî Create your first real playbook (bootstrap)
Create a file:

nano bootstrap.yml
Paste this exactly:

---
- name: Motorcade web bootstrap (Amazon Linux 2023)
  hosts: motorcade
  become: true

  vars:
    packages:
      - nginx
      - mariadb105-server
      - php
      - php-fpm
      - php-mysqlnd
      - php-gd
      - php-mbstring
      - php-xml
      - php-json
      - unzip
      - tar
      - curl
      - git

  tasks:
    - name: Update packages
      ansible.builtin.dnf:
        name: "*"
        state: latest
        update_cache: true

    - name: Install required packages
      ansible.builtin.dnf:
        name: "{{ packages }}"
        state: present

    - name: Enable and start nginx
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: nginx
        enabled: true
        state: started

    - name: Enable and start php-fpm
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: php-fpm
        enabled: true
        state: started

    - name: Enable and start mariadb
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: mariadb
        enabled: true
        state: started

    - name: Open HTTP/HTTPS in firewalld if present (no-fail)
      block:
        - name: Install firewalld
          ansible.builtin.dnf:
            name: firewalld
            state: present

        - name: Enable and start firewalld
          ansible.builtin.service:
            name: firewalld
            enabled: true
            state: started

        - name: Allow http/https
          ansible.posix.firewalld:
            service: "{{ item }}"
            permanent: true
            state: enabled
            immediate: true
          loop:
            - http
            - https
      rescue:
        - name: firewalld not available or failed ‚Äî continue
          ansible.builtin.debug:
            msg: "firewalld step skipped/failed; continuing"
Save + exit.

Step 8 ‚Äî Run it
Run:

ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini bootstrap.yml
This should end with no failures.

Step 9 ‚Äî Quick verification (2 commands)
After the playbook finishes, run:

ansible motorcade -i inventory.ini -a "systemctl status nginx --no-pager | head"
ansible motorcade -i inventory.ini -a "php -v | head -n 1"
Send me either:
a screenshot of the playbook result or

the last ~30 lines of the output

your Ansible install is broken ‚ùå

your playbook logic is wrong ‚ùå

It means one Ansible collection is missing on your local machine.

Ansible split many modules into collections.
firewalld lives in the ansible.posix collection.

‚úÖ The fix (ONE command)
Run this on your local machine (not the server):

ansible-galaxy collection install ansible.posix
You should see output like:

Installing 'ansible.posix' to /home/codeboy/.ansible/collections
That‚Äôs it.

üîÅ Re-run the playbook

Do not change anything else.

ansible-core does not bundle all collections

ansible.posix is intentionally external

This is extremely common on fresh installs

You did nothing wrong.

- name: Task name
  module_name:
    key: value
But your file has a task name without a valid module under it (or the module is mis-indented).

Correct firewalld task (copy-paste fix)
Open your playbook:

nano bootstrap.yml
Find the section around line ~65 and replace the firewall task with this exact block:

- name: Allow HTTP
  ansible.posix.firewalld:
    service: http
    permanent: true
    state: enabled
    immediate: true

- name: Allow HTTPS
  ansible.posix.firewalld:
    service: https
    permanent: true
    state: enabled
    immediate: true
IMPORTANT YAML RULES
ansible.posix.firewalld: must be indented under - name

No tabs ‚Äî spaces only

Every task must have one module

Optional but recommended: declare collections at the top
At the very top of bootstrap.yml, add:

- hosts: motorcade
  become: true
  collections:
    - ansible.posix
  tasks:
Then all tasks go under tasks:.

This prevents namespace resolution issues forever.

Re-run safely
ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini bootstrap.yml

What‚Äôs wrong (important)
In Ansible:

Only these keys are allowed at the play level:

hosts

become

vars

tasks

Right now, you have tasks defined outside of tasks::

- name: Replace curl-minimal with curl
- name: Install curl
These must be inside tasks:, or Ansible will behave unpredictably.

You also install curl twice (once explicitly, once via packages:).

‚úÖ Correct structure (this WILL work)
Replace your entire bootstrap.yml with this
Copy-paste exactly:

- name: Motorcade web bootstrap (Amazon Linux 2023)
  hosts: motorcade
  become: true

  vars:
    packages:
      - nginx
      - mariadb105-server
      - php
      - php-fpm
      - php-mysqlnd
      - php-gd
      - php-mbstring
      - php-xml
      - php-json
      - unzip
      - tar
      - git
      # curl intentionally NOT here

  tasks:
    - name: Replace curl-minimal with curl
      ansible.builtin.dnf:
        name: curl-minimal
        state: absent

    - name: Install curl
      ansible.builtin.dnf:
        name: curl
        state: present

    - name: Update all packages
      ansible.builtin.dnf:
        name: "*"
        state: latest
        update_cache: true

    - name: Install required packages
      ansible.builtin.dnf:
        name: "{{ packages }}"
        state: present
Why this fixes everything
‚úÖ Tasks are correctly nested
‚úÖ No duplicate curl install
‚úÖ Amazon Linux 2023 curl conflict resolved
‚úÖ Idempotent (safe to re-run)
‚úÖ Clean bootstrap base for WordPress / Nginx / PHP

Save & run

CTRL + O
ENTER
CTRL + X
Then run:

ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini bootstrap.yml

Step 2 ‚Äî Create an nginx site config (this is the key step)

Paste this exact content:

server {

    server_name _;

    root /var/www/motorcade;
    index index.php index.html;

    location / {
        try_files $uri $uri/ =404;
    }

    location ~ \.php$ {
        include fastcgi_params;
        fastcgi_pass unix:/run/php-fpm/www.sock;
        fastcgi_index index.php;
        fastcgi_param SCRIPT_FILENAME $document_root$fastcgi_script_name;
    }
}

Can we do what you just instructed and the rest of this setup with ansible?
ChatGPT said:
I‚Äôll show you how to translate what you just did (nginx site root + config + services) into an idempotent Ansible playbook you can run from your laptop, including inventory, variables, and the exact run commands.

Yes ‚Äî and it‚Äôs actually perfect for Ansible because everything we just did is deterministic and should be idempotent (safe to run repeatedly).

Below is a clean Ansible setup that will:

Create /var/www/motorcade

Write /var/www/motorcade/index.html

Install nginx + php-fpm (and firewalld if you want)

Write /etc/nginx/conf.d/motorcade.conf

Enable + start php-fpm and nginx

Reload nginx when the config changes

1) Folder layout on your local machine
From your local box:

mkdir -p ~/motorcade-ansible
cd ~/motorcade-ansible
Create these files:

inventory.ini

site.yml

2) inventory.ini
Replace the IP and key path if needed:

[motorcade]
motorcade-web-01 ansible_host=18.117.220.60 ansible_user=ec2-user ansible_ssh_private_key_file=~/.ssh/motorcade-key.pem ansible_python_interpreter=/usr/bin/python3
Quick connectivity test:

ansible motorcade -i inventory.ini -m ping
3) site.yml (the playbook)
This version uses only built-in modules except ansible.posix.firewalld (optional section).
If you don‚Äôt want firewalld at all, you can delete that block.

---
- name: Motorcade web bootstrap (Amazon Linux 2023)
  hosts: motorcade
  become: true

  vars:
    web_root: /var/www/motorcade
    index_html: "<h1>Motorcade site is live</h1>\n"
    nginx_site_conf: /etc/nginx/conf.d/motorcade.conf

    packages:
      - nginx
      - php-fpm

    open_ports:
      - http
      - https

  tasks:
    - name: Update package metadata + upgrade
      ansible.builtin.dnf:
        name: "*"
        state: latest
        update_cache: true

    - name: Install required packages
      ansible.builtin.dnf:
        name: "{{ packages }}"
        state: present

    - name: Create web root directory
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: "{{ web_root }}"
        state: directory
        owner: nginx
        group: nginx
        mode: "0755"

    - name: Write index.html
      ansible.builtin.copy:
        dest: "{{ web_root }}/index.html"
        content: "{{ index_html }}"
        owner: nginx
        group: nginx
        mode: "0644"

    - name: Write nginx site config
      ansible.builtin.copy:
        dest: "{{ nginx_site_conf }}"
        owner: root
        group: root
        mode: "0644"
        content: |
          server {
              listen 80;
              server_name _;

              root {{ web_root }};
              index index.php index.html;

              location / {
                  try_files $uri $uri/ =404;
              }

              location ~ \.php$ {
                  include fastcgi_params;
                  fastcgi_pass unix:/run/php-fpm/www.sock;
                  fastcgi_index index.php;
                  fastcgi_param SCRIPT_FILENAME $document_root$fastcgi_script_name;
              }
          }
      notify: Reload nginx

    - name: Validate nginx config
      ansible.builtin.command: nginx -t
      changed_when: false

    - name: Enable and start php-fpm
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: php-fpm
        enabled: true
        state: started

    - name: Enable and start nginx
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: nginx
        enabled: true
        state: started

    # OPTIONAL: firewalld (only if you actually want it on the instance)
    - name: Install firewalld (optional)
      ansible.builtin.dnf:
        name: firewalld
        state: present

    - name: Enable and start firewalld (optional)
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: firewalld
        enabled: true
        state: started

    - name: Allow HTTP/HTTPS in firewalld (optional)
      ansible.posix.firewalld:
        service: "{{ item }}"
        permanent: true
        state: enabled
        immediate: true
      loop: "{{ open_ports }}"
      ignore_errors: true

  handlers:
    - name: Reload nginx
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: nginx
        state: reloaded
4) Run it
Dry-run (shows what would change):

ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini site.yml --check
Real run:

ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini site.yml
Then visit:

One important note (AWS security
You said:
Why are we remaking the directory?
ChatGPT said:
Great question ‚Äî and this is actually a core Ansible concept, not wasted work.

Short answer: we‚Äôre not ‚Äúremaking‚Äù it every time.
We‚Äôre declaring that it must exist, and Ansible checks before doing anything.

What Ansible is doing (important mindset shift)
Ansible is state-based, not command-based.

You are not saying:

‚ÄúCreate this directory now‚Äù

You are saying:

‚ÄúI want this directory to exist in this state‚Äù

This line:

- name: Create web root directory
  ansible.builtin.file:
    path: /var/www/motorcade
    state: directory
    owner: nginx
    group: nginx
    mode: "0755"
Means:

If /var/www/motorcade does not exist ‚Üí create it

If it exists but ownership is wrong ‚Üí fix ownership

If it exists but permissions are wrong ‚Üí fix permissions

If it already matches ‚Üí do nothing

This is called idempotency.

Proof: Ansible won‚Äôt recreate it
If you run the playbook twice, you‚Äôll see:

TASK [Create web root directory]
ok: [motorcade-web-01]
Not:

changed
That tells you:

No recreation

No deletion

No overwrite

No downtime

Why this is actually protecting you
Imagine later you:

Deploy a theme

Change ownership accidentally

Run a plugin installer as root

Restore from backup

Without this task:

Your permissions silently break

nginx starts throwing 403 errors

You waste hours debugging

With this task:

Ansible fixes it automatically

You don‚Äôt even notice

Think of Ansible like infrastructure documentation that enforces itself
This playbook is saying:

‚ÄúThis server must always look like this‚Äù

That‚Äôs why it feels repetitive ‚Äî but it‚Äôs intentional safety, not duplication.

When would we NOT include it?
Only if:

The directory is managed by something else (Docker volume, EFS, etc.)

Or it‚Äôs ephemeral and intentionally mutable

For a web root? Always include it.

Bottom line
You‚Äôre not rebuilding anything.
You‚Äôre locking the server into a known-good state so it can never drift.

This is the correct approach ‚Äî and you‚Äôre doing it right üëç

Why bootstrap.yml exists
bootstrap.yml is usually the ‚Äúmake this machine ready for Ansible to do real work‚Äù playbook ‚Äî stuff like:

swap / basic OS tweaks

install missing baseline packages (curl, git, firewalld, python, etc.)

enable repos / fix Amazon Linux quirks (like curl-minimal conflicts)

Once that‚Äôs done, you typically move to a ‚Äúreal‚Äù playbook (site.yml, web.yml, etc.) that assumes the machine is ready.

So you‚Äôre right: bootstrap.yml installed curl so later tasks don‚Äôt break.

The clean way to structure this (so it never gets confusing again)
Option A (recommended): keep bootstrap, add a separate site playbook
You keep:

bootstrap.yml = base OS readiness (curl, git, firewall tools, etc.)

site.yml = nginx/php/mariadb + web content + config

ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini bootstrap.yml
ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini site.yml
This is the simplest mentally.

Option B: One ‚Äúmain‚Äù playbook that calls both
Create main.yml:

- import_playbook: bootstrap.yml
- import_playbook: site.yml
Then run:

ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini main.yml

You keep bootstrap.yml but tag bootstrap tasks:

- name: Replace curl-minimal with curl

    name: curl-minimal
    state: absent
  tags: [bootstrap]

    name: curl
    state: present
  tags: [bootstrap]
Then run only bootstrap pieces:

ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini bootstrap.yml --tags bootstrap
Or run everything:

ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini bootstrap.yml

You said:
Uploaded image
ChatGPT said:
You‚Äôre one character away from being correct üëç ‚Äî this is just Unix syntax, not an Ansible issue.

What went wrong (plain English)
You typed:

mv bootstrap.yml to 00-bootstrap.yml
Linux does not use the word to.
It thinks to is a filename, so it tries to move two sources into a destination that doesn‚Äôt exist.

That‚Äôs why you got:

mv: target '00-bootstrap.yml': No such file or directory
Correct command ‚úÖ
mv bootstrap.yml 00-bootstrap.yml
That‚Äôs it. No to.

Verify after renaming
ls
You should see:

00-bootstrap.yml
inventory.ini
Why this matters (important concept)
Unix commands are very literal:

mv <source> <destination>
No keywords. No arrows. No ‚Äúto‚Äù.

This is the same pattern you‚Äôll see everywhere:

scp local remote

üîú Next step: 03-nginx.yml
Now we stop using the default nginx welcome page and make nginx behave like a real web host.

Goals of 03-nginx.yml
Define /var/www/motorcade

Set ownership correctly

Create a real nginx server block

Remove default site

Reload nginx safely

No PHP yet. No WordPress yet. One responsibility only.

üìÑ Create 03-nginx.yml
You already opened it:

nano 03-nginx.yml
Paste this exactly:

---
- name: Motorcade ‚Äì configure Nginx
  hosts: motorcade
  become: true

  vars:
    web_root: /var/www/motorcade
    server_name: _

  tasks:
    - name: Create web root
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: "{{ web_root }}"
        state: directory
        owner: nginx
        group: nginx
        mode: "0755"

    - name: Create nginx server block
      ansible.builtin.copy:
        dest: /etc/nginx/conf.d/motorcade.conf
        content: |
          server {
              listen 80;
              server_name {{ server_name }};
              root {{ web_root }};
              index index.php index.html;

              location / {
                  try_files $uri $uri/ =404;
              }

              location ~ \.php$ {
                  include fastcgi_params;
                  fastcgi_pass unix:/run/php-fpm/www.sock;
                  fastcgi_index index.php;
                  fastcgi_param SCRIPT_FILENAME $document_root$fastcgi_script_name;
              }
          }

    - name: Remove default nginx config if present
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: /etc/nginx/conf.d/default.conf
        state: absent

    - name: Test nginx configuration
      ansible.builtin.command: nginx -t
      register: nginx_test
      changed_when: false
      failed_when: nginx_test.rc != 0

    - name: Reload nginx
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: nginx
        state: reloaded
Save and exit.

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Run it
ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini 03-nginx.yml

ChatGPT said:
I‚Äôll keep everything Ansible-driven and idempotent: first we‚Äôll safely determine MariaDB root access method, then create the WordPress DB + least-privilege user, and finally verify we can connect‚Äîwithout exposing credentials.

Perfect. Next we‚Äôll make Ansible create the WordPress DB + least-privilege user, but first we need to handle the #1 gotcha on Amazon Linux/MariaDB: root often authenticates via unix_socket, not a password. So we‚Äôll do this the safe way.

1) Install the Python DB driver (required for Ansible MySQL modules)
Create a new playbook:

nano 06-db-deps.yml
Paste:

---
- name: Motorcade ‚Äì DB deps (Python driver for Ansible)
  hosts: motorcade
  become: true

  tasks:
    - name: Install PyMySQL (Python MySQL driver)
      ansible.builtin.dnf:
        name: python3-pymysql
        state: present
Run it:

ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini 06-db-deps.yml
2) Create the WordPress DB + user (socket-auth safe)
Create:

nano 07-database.yml
Paste (this is production-safe and rerunnable):

---
- name: Motorcade ‚Äì create WordPress database and user
  hosts: motorcade
  become: true

  vars:
    wp_db_name: motorcade_wp
    wp_db_user: motorcade_user

    # Set this to a strong value (we‚Äôll improve storage next with Ansible Vault)
    wp_db_password: "CHANGE_ME_SECURELY"

    # MariaDB root socket location on most RHEL-family systems
    mariadb_socket: /var/lib/mysql/mysql.sock

  tasks:
    - name: Ensure MariaDB is running
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: mariadb
        state: started
        enabled: true

    - name: Create WordPress database
      community.mysql.mysql_db:
        name: "{{ wp_db_name }}"
        state: present
        encoding: utf8mb4
        collation: utf8mb4_unicode_ci
        login_unix_socket: "{{ mariadb_socket }}"

    - name: Create WordPress DB user with least privilege
      community.mysql.mysql_user:
        name: "{{ wp_db_user }}"
        password: "{{ wp_db_password }}"
        host: "localhost"
        priv: "{{ wp_db_name }}.*:ALL"
        state: present
        login_unix_socket: "{{ mariadb_socket }}"

    - name: Flush privileges
      community.mysql.mysql_user:
        name: "{{ wp_db_user }}"
        host: "localhost"
        state: present
        login_unix_socket: "{{ mariadb_socket }}"
        check_implicit_admin: true
Install the Ansible collection if you don‚Äôt have it yet
Run this once:

ansible-galaxy collection install community.mysql
Now run the playbook:

ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini 07-database.yml
3) Quick verification (still via Ansible)
Create:

nano 08-db-verify.yml
Paste:

---
- name: Motorcade ‚Äì verify WordPress DB exists
  hosts: motorcade
  become: true

  vars:
    mariadb_socket: /var/lib/mysql/mysql.sock
    wp_db_name: motorcade_wp

  tasks:
    - name: Show databases (should include motorcade_wp)
      community.mysql.mysql_query:
        query: "SHOW DATABASES;"
        login_unix_socket: "{{ mariadb_socket }}"
      register: dbs

    - name: Print databases
      ansible.builtin.debug:
        var: dbs.query_result
Run:

ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini 08-db-verify.yml
You should see motorcade_wp in the output.

We‚Äôre not recreating anything blindly‚ÄîAnsible‚Äôs state: present means:

Step 2 ‚Äî Create 07-database.yml
nano 07-database.yml
Paste (safe defaults; change passwords after if you want):

- name: Motorcade - database setup
  hosts: motorcade
  become: true

  vars:
    db_name: motorcade_wp
    db_user: motorcade_wp
    db_pass: "CHANGE_ME_STRONG_PASSWORD"

  tasks:
    - name: Ensure MariaDB is running
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: mariadb
        state: started
        enabled: true

    # Create DB and user using local socket auth (works on fresh MariaDB installs)
    - name: Create WordPress database
      community.mysql.mysql_db:
        name: "{{ db_name }}"
        state: present
        login_unix_socket: /var/lib/mysql/mysql.sock

    - name: Create WordPress DB user with privileges
      community.mysql.mysql_user:
        name: "{{ db_user }}"
        password: "{{ db_pass }}"
        host: "localhost"
        priv: "{{ db_name }}.*:ALL"
        state: present
        login_unix_socket: /var/lib/mysql/mysql.sock
Install the collection if you haven‚Äôt already:

ansible-galaxy collection install community.mysql
Run it:

ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini 07-database.yml
Step 3 ‚Äî Create 08-db-verify.yml (quick proof)
nano 08-db-verify.yml
Paste:

- name: Motorcade - verify database
  hosts: motorcade
  become: true

  vars:
    db_name: motorcade_wp

  tasks:
    - name: Show databases (verification)
      ansible.builtin.command: "mysql -e 'SHOW DATABASES;'"
      register: dbs
      changed_when: false

    - name: Print databases
      ansible.builtin.debug:
        var: dbs.stdout_lines

    - name: Assert WordPress DB exists
      ansible.builtin.assert:
        that:
          - "'{{ db_name }}' in dbs.stdout"
        fail_msg: "Database {{ db_name }} was NOT found."
        success_msg: "Database {{ db_name }} exists."
Run:

ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini 08-db-verify.yml

What‚Äôs ACTUALLY happening (important)
Even though Amazon Linux 2023 documents mention python3-pymysql, that package is not always present in the enabled repos by default on fresh EC2 installs.

So both of these fail on AL2023:

‚ùå python3-PyMySQL

‚ùå python3-pymysql

That‚Äôs why you‚Äôre seeing:

No package python3-pymysql available
The correct, reliable fix (production-safe)
On Amazon Linux 2023, the officially recommended approach is:

Install PyMySQL via pip, not DNF

Ansible fully supports this.

‚úÖ Correct solution: install via pip
We‚Äôll fix 06-db-deps.yml properly.

Step 1 ‚Äî Edit 06-db-deps.yml
nano 06-db-deps.yml
Step 2 ‚Äî Replace contents with THIS (exactly)
---
- name: Motorcade - database dependencies
  hosts: motorcade
  become: true

  tasks:
    - name: Ensure python3-pip is installed
      ansible.builtin.package:
        name: python3-pip
        state: present

    - name: Install PyMySQL via pip (Amazon Linux 2023)
      ansible.builtin.pip:
        name: pymysql
        executable: pip3
Save:

Enter

Method	Result
DNF packages	‚ùå unreliable on AL2023
EPEL	‚ùå not supported on AL2023
pip3	‚úÖ AWS-approved, stable

Below is the next clean, numbered playbook:

08-wordpress-install.yml = downloads + extracts WordPress into /var/www/motorcade, sets ownership/perms, creates a basic index.php placeholder (so you won‚Äôt see 403), and does NOT put DB creds in wp-config.php yet.

1) Create 08-wordpress-install.yml
From ~/motorcade-ansible:

nano 08-wordpress-install.yml
Paste this:

---
- name: Motorcade - install WordPress files
  hosts: motorcade
  become: true

  vars:
    web_root: /var/www/motorcade
    wp_version: latest
    wp_tmp_dir: /tmp/wordpress-install

    web_owner: nginx
    web_group: nginx

  tasks:
    - name: Ensure web root exists
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: "{{ web_root }}"
        state: directory
        owner: "{{ web_owner }}"
        group: "{{ web_group }}"
        mode: "0755"

    - name: Ensure temp directory exists
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: "{{ wp_tmp_dir }}"
        state: directory
        mode: "0755"

    - name: Download WordPress tarball
      ansible.builtin.get_url:
        url: "https://wordpress.org/{{ 'latest' if wp_version == 'latest' else ('wordpress-' ~ wp_version) }}.tar.gz"
        dest: "{{ wp_tmp_dir }}/wordpress.tar.gz"
        mode: "0644"

    - name: Extract WordPress tarball
      ansible.builtin.unarchive:
        src: "{{ wp_tmp_dir }}/wordpress.tar.gz"
        dest: "{{ wp_tmp_dir }}"
        remote_src: true

    # This prevents nuking your webroot if you already created files
    - name: Check if WordPress already present
      ansible.builtin.stat:
        path: "{{ web_root }}/wp-settings.php"
      register: wp_present

    - name: Copy WordPress into web root (first install only)
      ansible.builtin.command: >
        rsync -a "{{ wp_tmp_dir }}/wordpress/" "{{ web_root }}/"
      args:
        creates: "{{ web_root }}/wp-settings.php"
      when: not wp_present.stat.exists

    - name: Ensure correct ownership for WordPress tree
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: "{{ web_root }}"
        state: directory
        owner: "{{ web_owner }}"
        group: "{{ web_group }}"
        recurse: true

    - name: Set safe directory permissions (0755)
      ansible.builtin.command: >
        find "{{ web_root }}" -type d -exec chmod 0755 {} \;
      changed_when: false

    - name: Set safe file permissions (0644)
      ansible.builtin.command: >
        find "{{ web_root }}" -type f -exec chmod 0644 {} \;
      changed_when: false

    # If your nginx config is pointing at /var/www/motorcade but no index exists,
    # nginx can show 403. WordPress provides index.php, but this is a safety net.
    - name: Ensure index.php exists (safety net)
      ansible.builtin.copy:
        dest: "{{ web_root }}/index.php"
        owner: "{{ web_owner }}"
        group: "{{ web_group }}"
        mode: "0644"
        content: |
          <?php
          // Safety net file. If WordPress is present, it will overwrite this naturally.
          echo "Motorcade web root is live.";
          ?>
      when: not wp_present.stat.exists

    - name: Clean up temp directory
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: "{{ wp_tmp_dir }}"
        state: absent
Save: Ctrl+O, Enter, Ctrl+X

2) Run it
ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini 08-wordpress-install.yml
3) Quick verify (2 ways)
A) Confirm WordPress files exist
ssh -i ~/.ssh/motorcade-key.pem ec2-user@18.117.220.60 "sudo ls -la /var/www/motorcade | head"
B) Confirm nginx serves the site root (should no longer be 403)

http://18.117.220.60

You said:
What makes recovery easier?
ChatGPT said:
Great question ‚Äî this is exactly the right thing to ask at this point.

Short answer up front:

Ansible Vault (Option A) makes recovery safer and more reliable.
Plaintext (Option B) makes recovery faster but riskier.

Now let me explain why, in practical, real-world terms ‚Äî not theory.

What ‚Äúrecovery‚Äù actually means here
Recovery usually means one of these situations:

üí• EC2 instance is lost ‚Üí you spin up a new one

üß™ You break something experimenting ‚Üí you want a clean rebuild

üîÅ You want to recreate the same environment months later

üë§ Someone else (or future you) needs to deploy it again

In all cases, recovery = rerunning the playbooks with confidence.

Option A ‚Äî Ansible Vault (Recommended)
What it is
Secrets (DB password) are encrypted

Stored with your playbooks

Unlocked only when you run Ansible

What recovery looks like
ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini 09-wordpress-config.yml --ask-vault-pass
You type one password, everything works.

Why this is good for recovery
‚úÖ You never lose the DB password
It lives encrypted in Git / backups

‚úÖ One command rebuilds everything
No ‚Äúwhat was the password again?‚Äù moments

‚úÖ Safe to store anywhere
GitHub, backups, USB, cloud ‚Äî doesn‚Äôt matter

‚úÖ Future-proof
6 months from now, it still works the same way

Tradeoff
‚ùå Slightly more setup
‚ùå You must remember one vault password

Option B ‚Äî Plaintext Variables (Fast but Fragile)
What it is
DB password is written directly in YAML

Easy to read, easy to copy

What recovery looks like
ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini 09-wordpress-config.yml
No prompts, instant run.

Why this can be easier short-term
‚úÖ Fastest to set up
‚úÖ No vault password to remember
‚úÖ Less moving parts while learning

Why recovery can hurt later
‚ö†Ô∏è If the file is lost, the password is lost
‚ö†Ô∏è If someone sees the repo, they see the password
‚ö†Ô∏è Harder to rotate credentials safely

This is fine for:

Local dev

Short-lived test servers

Learning

Not ideal for:

Production

Anything you might rebuild later under stress

Side-by-side: recovery comparison
Scenario	Vault (A)	Plaintext (B)
Rebuild server	‚úÖ One command	‚ö†Ô∏è Must ensure password still exists
Store in Git	‚úÖ Safe	‚ùå Dangerous
Future you	‚úÖ Clear & safe	‚ö†Ô∏è ‚ÄúWhy did I do this?‚Äù
Under pressure	‚úÖ Predictable	‚ö†Ô∏è Risky
Setup speed	‚ö†Ô∏è Slightly slower	‚úÖ Fastest
My honest recommendation for you
Given:

This is Motorcade

You‚Äôve already invested real time

You want reinstall confidence

You‚Äôre using Ansible correctly

üëâ Option A (Ansible Vault) is the right long-term move.

But ‚Äî and this matters ‚Äî

If you want:

‚ÄúI just want to see WordPress come up right now‚Äù

Then Option B is acceptable temporarily, and we can migrate to Vault later cleanly.

Perfect ‚Äî Option A (Ansible Vault) is the right call for recovery.

Here‚Äôs the clean way to do it with what you already have.

1) Create the vault secrets file (encrypted)
From ~/motorcade-ansible:

ansible-vault create group_vars/motorcade/vault.yml
It will ask you to set a vault password, then open an editor.

Paste this inside:

vault_wp_db_password: "CHANGE_ME_SECURELY"
Save/exit.

If group_vars/motorcade/ doesn‚Äôt exist yet, create it first:

mkdir -p group_vars/motorcade
ansible-vault create group_vars/motorcade/vault.yml
2) Create a non-secret vars file (safe to keep in Git)
Create:

nano group_vars/motorcade/main.yml
Paste:

wp_db_name: motorcade_wp
wp_db_user: motorcade_user
wp_db_password: "{{ vault_wp_db_password }}"
Save.

3) Fix 07-database.yml to stop storing passwords inside it
Open it:

nano 07-database.yml
Do both of these:

A) Remove the whole vars: block from the playbook
(Anything like wp_db_name, wp_db_user, wp_db_password inside 07-database.yml)

B) Ensure the play uses the mysql modules you installed
A correct minimal 07-database.yml should look like this:

- name: Motorcade - database provisioning
  hosts: motorcade
  become: true

  tasks:
    - name: Ensure MariaDB is running
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: mariadb
        state: started
        enabled: true

    - name: Create WordPress database
      community.mysql.mysql_db:
        name: "{{ wp_db_name }}"
        state: present
        login_unix_socket: /var/lib/mysql/mysql.sock

    - name: Create WordPress database user
      community.mysql.mysql_user:
        name: "{{ wp_db_user }}"
        password: "{{ wp_db_password }}"
        priv: "{{ wp_db_name }}.*:ALL"
        host: localhost
        state: present
        login_unix_socket: /var/lib/mysql/mysql.sock
‚úÖ This uses the socket login, so we don‚Äôt have to mess with root passwords right now.

4) Run the database playbook using the vault password
ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini 07-database.yml --ask-vault-pass
You should see it create the DB and user.

5) (Optional but recommended) Make running easier without typing the vault password every time
Create a local file (DO NOT commit it):

nano .vault_pass
Put your vault password on the first line. Save.

Lock it down:

chmod 600 .vault_pass
Run like:

ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini 07-database.yml --vault-password-file ./.vault_pass
Add to .gitignore:

echo ".vault_pass" >> .gitignore
Quick answer to ‚Äúwhat makes recovery easier?‚Äù
With this setup:

You can rebuild a fresh server by re-running playbooks

Your secrets stay encrypted in the repo

The only thing you must not lose is the vault password (or your .vault_pass file if you use it locally)

Here‚Äôs the clean, production-style order (secure + easiest recovery):

1) Vault-first secrets (you already did this ‚úÖ)

Removes manual browser config

Prevents secrets from ever living in repo plaintext

Makes rebuilds 1-command

Key points:

Set DB creds from your vars

Add unique keys/salts

Set FS_METHOD to direct only if needed (often not)

3) Lock down filesystem + Nginx (quick hardening)
Do this before WP-CLI install:

Disable PHP execution in uploads/

Add security headers

Ensure proper client_max_body_size for uploads

Consider basic rate limiting on /wp-login.php and /xmlrpc.php (or disable xmlrpc if unused)

4) WP-CLI ‚Äúcore install‚Äù (Option B)
Why it‚Äôs best practice:

Fully automated provisioning (no browser wizard)

Repeatable across environments

Easy DR/restore

You‚Äôll do:

Download WP-CLI (or install package)

Run:

wp core install

set permalink structure

remove default plugins/themes

install your baseline theme/plugins

create required pages (Home, Contact, etc.)

5) Backups / Recovery hooks (what makes recovery easiest)
Best practice recovery is stateless app + stateful data:

Web server can be rebuilt from playbooks anytime

Persist/backup:

/var/www/motorcade/wp-content/ (themes/uploads/plugins)

MariaDB database dump

Store backups in S3 (or equivalent) + enable versioning

Minimum DR artifacts:

Vault file (encrypted) + vault password method (prefer vault password file stored securely, not in repo)

wp-content backup

Thought for 19s
Awesome ‚Äî we‚Äôre doing 09 now: generate a real wp-config.php from Vault, remove the placeholder ‚ÄúMotorcade web root is live‚Äù, and make WordPress ready to load.

I‚Äôm going to give you a drop-in playbook that:

Auto-detects your WordPress web root (/usr/share/nginx/html vs /var/www/motorcade)

Pulls DB creds from your vars/vault

Fetches fresh WordPress salts from WordPress.org

Writes wp-config.php with secure permissions

Removes the placeholder index.php if it contains the ‚ÄúMotorcade web root is live‚Äù text

1) Create 09-wp-config.yml
From ~/motorcade-ansible:

nano 09-wp-config.yml
Paste exactly:

---
- name: Motorcade - generate wp-config.php from Vault
  hosts: motorcade
  become: true

  vars:
    candidate_roots:
      - /usr/share/nginx/html
      - /var/www/motorcade

    web_owner: nginx
    web_group: nginx

    # WordPress DB settings come from group_vars/motorcade/main.yml + vault
    # wp_db_name: motorcade_wp
    # wp_db_user: motorcade_user
    # wp_db_password: "{{ vault_wp_db_password }}"
    wp_db_host: localhost

  tasks:
    - name: Detect WordPress root by checking for wp-settings.php
      ansible.builtin.stat:
        path: "{{ item }}/wp-settings.php"
      loop: "{{ candidate_roots }}"
      register: wp_root_stats

    - name: Set wp_root fact to the first matching root
      ansible.builtin.set_fact:
        wp_root: "{{ (wp_root_stats.results | selectattr('stat.exists','equalto',true) | map(attribute='item') | list | first) | default('') }}"

    - name: Fail if WordPress root could not be detected
      ansible.builtin.fail:
        msg: "Could not find WordPress in {{ candidate_roots }} (missing wp-settings.php). Run 08-wordpress-install.yml first or confirm web_root."
      when: wp_root == ""

    - name: Show detected WordPress root
      ansible.builtin.debug:
        msg: "Detected WordPress root: {{ wp_root }}"

    - name: Fetch WordPress salts
      ansible.builtin.uri:
        url: https://api.wordpress.org/secret-key/1.1/salt/
        return_content: true
      register: wp_salts

    - name: Ensure wp-config-sample.php exists
      ansible.builtin.stat:
        path: "{{ wp_root }}/wp-config-sample.php"
      register: wp_sample

    - name: Fail if wp-config-sample.php is missing
      ansible.builtin.fail:
        msg: "wp-config-sample.php not found in {{ wp_root }}. WordPress install may be incomplete."
      when: not wp_sample.stat.exists

    - name: Create wp-config.php from sample if not already present
      ansible.builtin.copy:
        src: "{{ wp_root }}/wp-config-sample.php"
        dest: "{{ wp_root }}/wp-config.php"
        remote_src: true
        owner: "{{ web_owner }}"
        group: "{{ web_group }}"
        mode: "0640"
      args:
        force: false

    - name: Set DB_NAME in wp-config.php
      ansible.builtin.replace:
        path: "{{ wp_root }}/wp-config.php"
        regexp: "define\\(\\s*'DB_NAME'\\s*,\\s*'[^']*'\\s*\\);"
        replace: "define( 'DB_NAME', '{{ wp_db_name }}' );"

    - name: Set DB_USER in wp-config.php
      ansible.builtin.replace:
        path: "{{ wp_root }}/wp-config.php"
        regexp: "define\\(\\s*'DB_USER'\\s*,\\s*'[^']*'\\s*\\);"
        replace: "define( 'DB_USER', '{{ wp_db_user }}' );"

    - name: Set DB_PASSWORD in wp-config.php
      ansible.builtin.replace:
        path: "{{ wp_root }}/wp-config.php"
        regexp: "define\\(\\s*'DB_PASSWORD'\\s*,\\s*'[^']*'\\s*\\);"
        replace: "define( 'DB_PASSWORD', '{{ wp_db_password }}' );"

    - name: Set DB_HOST in wp-config.php
      ansible.builtin.replace:
        path: "{{ wp_root }}/wp-config.php"
        regexp: "define\\(\\s*'DB_HOST'\\s*,\\s*'[^']*'\\s*\\);"
        replace: "define( 'DB_HOST', '{{ wp_db_host }}' );"

    # Replace the entire salts block with fresh salts.
    # This targets the common sample markers: AUTH_KEY ... NONCE_SALT.
    - name: Replace salts block in wp-config.php
      ansible.builtin.replace:
        path: "{{ wp_root }}/wp-config.php"
        regexp: "(?s)define\\(\\s*'AUTH_KEY'.*?define\\(\\s*'NONCE_SALT'\\s*,\\s*'[^']*'\\s*\\);"
        replace: "{{ wp_salts.content | trim }}"

    - name: Ensure wp-config.php ownership and permissions are correct
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: "{{ wp_root }}/wp-config.php"
        owner: "{{ web_owner }}"
        group: "{{ web_group }}"
        mode: "0640"

    # Remove placeholder index.php ONLY if it contains our message
    - name: Check current index.php content
      ansible.builtin.slurp:
        src: "{{ wp_root }}/index.php"
      register: index_php
      ignore_errors: true

    - name: Remove placeholder index.php if it contains 'Motorcade web root is live'
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: "{{ wp_root }}/index.php"
        state: absent
      when:
        - index_php is defined
        - index_php.content is defined
        - (index_php.content | b64decode) is search("Motorcade web root is live")

    - name: Ensure WordPress index.php exists after placeholder removal
      ansible.builtin.stat:
        path: "{{ wp_root }}/index.php"
      register: wp_index

    - name: Fail if WordPress index.php is missing (unexpected)
      ansible.builtin.fail:
        msg: "index.php is missing in {{ wp_root }} after cleanup. WordPress files may be incomplete."
      when: not wp_index.stat.exists
Save:

Ctrl + O, Enter

- name: Motorcade - install WP-CLI
  hosts: motorcade
  become: true

  tasks:
    - name: Download wp-cli.phar
      ansible.builtin.get_url:
        url: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/wp-cli/builds/gh-pages/phar/wp-cli.phar
        dest: /usr/local/bin/wp
        mode: '0755'

    - name: Verify wp-cli is installed
      ansible.builtin.command: wp --info
      register: wpcli_info
      changed_when: false

    - name: Show wp-cli info
      ansible.builtin.debug:
        var: wpcli_info.stdout

Great screenshot ‚Äî this is a very common Ansible gotcha, and the fix is simple. Nothing is broken.

‚ùå What happened (plain English)
You ran:

ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini 09.5-wp-cli.yml
‚Ä¶and Ansible responded:

ERROR! Attempting to decrypt but no vault secrets found

2) Update your WP install playbook to use vault + site vars
Create 10-wp-install.yml:

cat > 10-wp-install.yml <<'YAML'
- name: Motorcade - install WordPress core via WP-CLI
  hosts: motorcade
  become: true

  vars_files:
    - group_vars/motorcade/site.yml

  vars:
    wp_root: /var/www/motorcade

  tasks:
    - name: Verify wp-cli works
      command: wp --info
      register: wp_info
      changed_when: false

    - name: Check if WordPress is already installed
      command: wp core is-installed --path={{ wp_root }}
      register: wp_installed
      changed_when: false
      failed_when: false

    - name: Install WordPress (only if not installed)
      command: >
        wp core install
        --path={{ wp_root }}
        --url={{ wp_site_url }}
        --title={{ wp_site_title }}
        --admin_user={{ vault_wp_admin_user }}
        --admin_password={{ vault_wp_admin_password }}
        --admin_email={{ wp_admin_email }}
        --skip-email
      when: wp_installed.rc != 0

    - name: Force correct siteurl/home (idempotent)
      command: >
        wp option update {{ item.key }} {{ item.val }}
        --path={{ wp_root }}
      loop:
        - { key: "siteurl", val: "{{ wp_site_url }}" }
        - { key: "home",    val: "{{ wp_site_url }}" }
      changed_when: false
YAML
Run it:

Item	Where it belongs	Why
DB creds	Vault ‚Üí wp-config playbook	PHP needs them
Admin user	Vault ‚Üí WP-CLI	Stored in DB, not config
Admin email	Vault ‚Üí WP-CLI	WordPress option
Salts	wp-config playbook	PHP runtime

Below is the safest way to do it: 10 will be idempotent (it won‚Äôt reinstall WP if it‚Äôs already installed), and it won‚Äôt touch 09.5.

1) Add these to the vault (if not already)
Edit your vault:

ansible-vault edit group_vars/motorcade/vault.yml
Add (or confirm) these keys:

2) Ensure group_vars/motorcade/main.yml maps vault ‚Üí normal vars

nano group_vars/motorcade/main.yml
Make sure you have mappings like:

(Keep your DB mappings the same way too, if you already have them.)

3) Create 10-wp-core-install.yml
Create the new playbook:

nano 10-wp-core-install.yml
Paste this:

- name: Motorcade - WordPress core install + admin user (WP-CLI)
  hosts: motorcade
  become: true

  vars:
    # Must match your real WP root (your logs showed /var/www/motorcade)
    wp_root: /var/www/motorcade

    # Web user/group (Amazon Linux nginx default is usually nginx)
    web_owner: nginx
    web_group: nginx

  tasks:
    - name: Ensure wp-cli exists
      ansible.builtin.command: wp --info
      register: wpcli_info
      changed_when: false

    - name: Check if WordPress is already installed
      ansible.builtin.command: wp core is-installed --path="{{ wp_root }}" --allow-root
      register: wp_installed
      failed_when: false
      changed_when: false

    - name: Run WordPress core install (only if not installed)
      ansible.builtin.command: >
        wp core install
        --path="{{ wp_root }}"
        --url="{{ wp_site_url }}"
        --title="{{ wp_site_title }}"
        --admin_user="{{ wp_admin_user }}"
        --admin_password="{{ wp_admin_password }}"
        --admin_email="{{ wp_admin_email }}"
        --skip-email
        --allow-root
      when: wp_installed.rc != 0

    - name: Ensure siteurl/home are set correctly
      ansible.builtin.command: >
        wp option update {{ item.key }} "{{ item.val }}"
        --path="{{ wp_root }}" --allow-root
      loop:
        - { key: "siteurl", val: "{{ wp_site_url }}" }
        - { key: "home",    val: "{{ wp_site_url }}" }
      changed_when: false

    - name: Fix ownership after WP-CLI actions
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: "{{ wp_root }}"
        owner: "{{ web_owner }}"
        group: "{{ web_group }}"
        recurse: true
Why this is safe
It checks wp core is-installed first.

It only runs wp core install if WP is not installed.

It doesn‚Äôt modify 09.5 at all.

It resets permissions after WP-CLI actions (prevents weird file ownership problems).

ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini 10-wp-core-install.yml --ask-vault-pass

DNS: what to set (best practice)
At your DNS provider for motorcade.vip:

Required
A record:

Host: @

Value: your server public IP (looks like 18.117.220.60)

TTL: 300 (5 min) if possible

Recommended
A record for www:

Host: www

Value: same IP (18.117.220.60)

TTL: 300
(or use CNAME www ‚Üí @ if your provider prefers)

One important warning (so HTTPS doesn‚Äôt bite you)
Your WordPress URL is already https://motorcade.vip.

That‚Äôs fine only if you‚Äôre ready to issue a real cert (Let‚Äôs Encrypt) after DNS points to the server.
If you haven‚Äôt done TLS yet, browsers may show errors until cert is installed.

So the clean sequence is:

‚úÖ WP installed (done)

DNS A record ‚Üí server IP

Wait until DNS resolves

Run your TLS/Let‚Äôs Encrypt playbook (or certbot)

Confirm https://motorcade.vip loads

What the 403 Forbidden means (in your case)

The line that confused you:

-bash: try_files: command not found
That‚Äôs normal.
try_files is not a shell command ‚Äî it only belongs inside an nginx config file.

So now we fix that.

The LAST thing preventing the site from loading
Your current /etc/nginx/conf.d/motorcade.conf has this:

location / {
    try_files $uri $uri/ =404;
}
That breaks WordPress routing.

WordPress requires requests to fall back to index.php.

‚úÖ Correct WordPress Nginx block (THIS is the fix)
Open the file:

sudo nano /etc/nginx/conf.d/motorcade.conf
Replace only the location / block with this:

location / {
    try_files $uri $uri/ /index.php?$args;
}
Do not change anything else.

Your full file should look like this:

server {
    listen 80;
    server_name motorcade.vip www.motorcade.vip;

    root /var/www/motorcade;
    index index.php index.html;

    location / {
        try_files $uri $uri/ /index.php?$args;
    }

    location ~ \.php$ {
        include fastcgi_params;
        fastcgi_pass unix:/run/php-fpm/www.sock;
        fastcgi_index index.php;
        fastcgi_param SCRIPT_FILENAME $document_root$fastcgi_script_name;
    }
}
Save (Ctrl+O, Enter) and exit (Ctrl+X).

Reload Nginx
sudo nginx -t
sudo systemctl reload nginx
You should NOT see the conflicting server warning anymore.

200 OK

Inbound 80/443 not allowed

Or ephemeral ports are blocked

---
- name: Motorcade - finalize WordPress vhost + SSL + health checks
  hosts: motorcade
  become: true

  vars:
    wp_root: /var/www/motorcade
    wp_owner: nginx
    wp_group: nginx

    domain_primary: motorcade.vip
    domain_aliases:
      - www.motorcade.vip

    # If you already installed wp-cli in 9.5, this just verifies it.
    wp_cli_bin: /usr/local/bin/wp

    # Amazon Linux 2023 typical paths
    nginx_conf_dir: /etc/nginx/conf.d
    nginx_site_conf: /etc/nginx/conf.d/motorcade.conf

    # certbot setup
    certbot_pkg: certbot
    certbot_nginx_pkg: python3-certbot-nginx

    # If you need an email for Let's Encrypt registration (recommended)
    le_email: "{{ vault_admin_email | default('patrick@motorcade.vip') }}"

    # WordPress settings (expected from group_vars/motorcade/main.yml + vault)
    wp_db_name: "{{ wp_db_name | default('motorcade_wp') }}"
    wp_db_user: "{{ wp_db_user | default('motorcade_user') }}"
    wp_db_password: "{{ wp_db_password }}"
    wp_db_host: "{{ wp_db_host | default('localhost') }}"

    wp_admin_user: "{{ wp_admin_user }}"
    wp_admin_password: "{{ wp_admin_password }}"
    wp_admin_email: "{{ wp_admin_email | default('patrick@motorcade.vip') }}"

    wp_siteurl: "https://{{ domain_primary }}"
    wp_home: "https://{{ domain_primary }}"
    wp_title: "Motorcade Security Solutions"

  tasks:
    - name: Ensure required packages are installed
      ansible.builtin.package:
        name:
          - nginx
          - php-fpm
          - php-mysqlnd
          - php-cli
          - curl
          - unzip
          - tar
          - "{{ certbot_pkg }}"
          - "{{ certbot_nginx_pkg }}"
        state: present

    - name: Ensure services are enabled and started
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: "{{ item }}"
        state: started
        enabled: true
      loop:
        - nginx
        - php-fpm

    # --- wp-cli (verify or install safely) ---
    - name: Check if wp-cli exists
      ansible.builtin.stat:
        path: "{{ wp_cli_bin }}"
      register: wpcli_stat

    - name: Download wp-cli.phar (only if missing)
      ansible.builtin.get_url:
        url: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/wp-cli/builds/gh-pages/phar/wp-cli.phar
        dest: /tmp/wp-cli.phar
        mode: "0644"
      when: not wpcli_stat.stat.exists

    - name: Install wp-cli to /usr/local/bin/wp (only if missing)
      ansible.builtin.copy:
        src: /tmp/wp-cli.phar
        dest: "{{ wp_cli_bin }}"
        mode: "0755"
        remote_src: true
      when: not wpcli_stat.stat.exists

    - name: Verify wp-cli works
      ansible.builtin.command: "{{ wp_cli_bin }} --info"
      register: wpcli_info
      changed_when: false

    # --- WordPress core (idempotent) ---
    - name: Ensure WordPress root exists
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: "{{ wp_root }}"
        state: directory
        owner: "{{ wp_owner }}"
        group: "{{ wp_group }}"
        mode: "0755"

    - name: Check if WordPress is already installed (wp core is-installed)
      ansible.builtin.command: >
        {{ wp_cli_bin }} core is-installed --path={{ wp_root }} --allow-root
      register: wp_is_installed
      changed_when: false
      failed_when: false

    - name: Download WordPress core if needed
      ansible.builtin.command: >
        {{ wp_cli_bin }} core download --force --path={{ wp_root }} --allow-root
      when: wp_is_installed.rc != 0

    - name: Ensure wp-config.php exists (create if missing)
      ansible.builtin.stat:
        path: "{{ wp_root }}/wp-config.php"
      register: wpconfig_stat

    - name: Create wp-config.php (only if missing)
      ansible.builtin.command: >
        {{ wp_cli_bin }} config create
        --path={{ wp_root }}
        --dbname={{ wp_db_name }}
        --dbuser={{ wp_db_user }}
        --dbpass={{ wp_db_password }}
        --dbhost={{ wp_db_host }}
        --skip-check
        --allow-root
      when: not wpconfig_stat.stat.exists

    - name: Install WordPress core (only if not installed)
      ansible.builtin.command: >
        {{ wp_cli_bin }} core install
        --path={{ wp_root }}
        --url={{ wp_siteurl }}
        --title="{{ wp_title }}"
        --admin_user={{ wp_admin_user }}
        --admin_password={{ wp_admin_password }}
        --admin_email={{ wp_admin_email }}
        --skip-email
        --allow-root
      when: wp_is_installed.rc != 0

    - name: Ensure WP home/siteurl are https
      ansible.builtin.command: >
        {{ wp_cli_bin }} option update {{ item.key }} {{ item.val }}
        --path={{ wp_root }} --allow-root
      loop:
        - { key: "siteurl", val: "{{ wp_siteurl }}" }
        - { key: "home",    val: "{{ wp_home }}" }

    # --- NGINX: disable default catch-all and define clean vhost ---
    - name: Disable default_server file if present
      ansible.builtin.shell: |
        set -e
        if [ -f "{{ nginx_conf_dir }}/00-default.conf" ]; then
          mv "{{ nginx_conf_dir }}/00-default.conf" "{{ nginx_conf_dir }}/
