1) Create 11-nginx-ssl.yml
Save this as 11-nginx-ssl.yml in the same folder as your other playbooks:

---
- name: Motorcade - Nginx vhost + disable default + SSL
  hosts: motorcade
  become: true

  vars:
    domain_primary: motorcade.vip
    domain_aliases:
      - www.motorcade.vip

    web_root: /var/www/motorcade
    nginx_conf_dir: /etc/nginx/conf.d
    nginx_site_conf: /etc/nginx/conf.d/motorcade.conf

    # use vault_admin_email if you have it, otherwise default
    le_email: "{{ vault_admin_email | default('patrick@motorcade.vip') }}"

  tasks:
    - name: Ensure nginx + certbot packages present
      ansible.builtin.package:
        name:
          - nginx
          - certbot
          - python3-certbot-nginx
        state: present

    - name: Ensure nginx is running
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: nginx
        state: started
        enabled: true

    - name: Ensure web root exists
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: "{{ web_root }}"
        state: directory
        mode: "0755"

    # --- Disable catch-all default_server that can steal traffic ---
    - name: Disable 00-default.conf if present
      ansible.builtin.shell: |
        set -e
        if [ -f "{{ nginx_conf_dir }}/00-default.conf" ]; then
          mv "{{ nginx_conf_dir }}/00-default.conf" "{{ nginx_conf_dir }}/00-default.conf.disabled"
        fi
      args:
        executable: /bin/bash
      changed_when: false

    # --- Create a clean vhost (HTTP only first) ---
    - name: Write motorcade nginx vhost (HTTP)
      ansible.builtin.copy:
        dest: "{{ nginx_site_conf }}"
        mode: "0644"
        content: |
          server {
              listen 80;
              server_name {{ domain_primary }}{% for d in domain_aliases %} {{ d }}{% endfor %};

              root {{ web_root }};
              index index.php index.html;

              # WordPress front-controller
              location / {
                  try_files $uri $uri/ /index.php?$args;
              }

              location ~ \.php$ {
                  include fastcgi_params;
                  fastcgi_pass unix:/run/php-fpm/www.sock;
                  fastcgi_index index.php;
                  fastcgi_param SCRIPT_FILENAME $document_root$fastcgi_script_name;
              }

              location ~* \.(js|css|png|jpg|jpeg|gif|ico|svg|webp)$ {
                  expires 30d;
                  add_header Cache-Control "public, no-transform";
              }
          }

    - name: Test nginx config
      ansible.builtin.command: nginx -t
      changed_when: false

    - name: Reload nginx
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: nginx
        state: reloaded

    # --- Obtain/Install SSL via certbot nginx plugin ---
    # This edits the vhost safely and adds the 443 server block + redirect.
    - name: Request/Install Let's Encrypt cert (non-interactive)
      ansible.builtin.command: >
        certbot --nginx
        -d {{ domain_primary }}
        {% for d in domain_aliases %}-d {{ d }} {% endfor %}
        --non-interactive
        --agree-tos
        -m {{ le_email }}
        --redirect
      register: certbot_run
      changed_when: "'Congratulations' in certbot_run.stdout or 'successfully' in certbot_run.stdout.lower()"
      failed_when: certbot_run.rc != 0

    # --- Health checks ---
    - name: Verify local HTTP responds
      ansible.builtin.command: curl -I http://127.0.0.1/
      register: curl_local
      changed_when: false

    - name: Show local curl headers
      ansible.builtin.debug:
        var: curl_local.stdout_lines

    - name: Verify nginx is listening on 80 and 443
      ansible.builtin.shell: |
        ss -lntp | egrep ':(80|443)\b' || true
      register: listen_ports
      changed_when: false

    - name: Show listening ports
      ansible.builtin.debug:
        var: listen_ports.stdout_lines

        error_page 500 502 503 504 /50x.html;
        location = /50x.html {}

}
Why this matters
That server_name _; block is always a catch-all

It lives after the include /etc/nginx/conf.d/*.conf;

It steals traffic before your motorcade.conf

Disabling 00-default.conf was necessary but not sufficient

This explains everything you observed:

curl http://127.0.0.1 works

curl http://18.117.220.60 works

Browser sometimes times out or hits wrong content

HTTPS behaved strangely

DNS was fine the whole time (your dig @8.8.8.8 proved it)

So: this is not DNS, not T-Mobile, not AWS networking

It is nginx precedence.

The correct fix (safe, minimal, no WP breakage)
We do ONE thing:
üëâ Remove or comment out the default server {} block inside nginx.conf

Your real vhosts should live in conf.d/, not in nginx.conf.

server {
    listen 80;

    server_name _;

Add this task to 11-nginx-ssl.yml
- name: Disable built-in default server block in nginx.conf
  ansible.builtin.replace:
    path: /etc/nginx/nginx.conf
    regexp: 'server\s*\{[\s\S]*?error_page 500 502 503 504 /50x\.html;[\s\S]*?\}'
    replace: |
      # Default server block disabled by Ansible
      # (All vhosts live in conf.d)
  notify: reload nginx
And add a handler:

handlers:
  - name: reload nginx
    ansible.builtin.service:
      name: nginx
      state: reloaded
This is safe, idempotent, and won‚Äôt touch WP or PHP.

Add a new file: 11-nginx-default-server-fix.yml
This approach is safe and idempotent:

It comments out the default server block only if it exists

It doesn‚Äôt touch your real site in /etc/nginx/conf.d/motorcade.conf

Create:

---
- name: Disable built-in default server block in nginx.conf (Amazon Linux nginx)
  hosts: web
  become: true

  tasks:
    - name: Backup nginx.conf before modifications
      ansible.builtin.copy:
        src: /etc/nginx/nginx.conf
        dest: /etc/nginx/nginx.conf.bak
        remote_src: true
        mode: "0644"

    - name: Comment out default catch-all server block in nginx.conf (if present)
      ansible.builtin.replace:
        path: /etc/nginx/nginx.conf
        regexp: '(\n\s*server\s*\{\n(?:.|\n)*?\n\s*\}\n)'
        replace: |
          \n    # --- disabled by Ansible: default catch-all server block ---
          # \1
          # --- end disabled block ---
      register: nginxconf_changed

    - name: Test nginx config
      ansible.builtin.command: nginx -t
      changed_when: false

    - name: Reload nginx if nginx.conf changed
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: nginx
        state: reloaded
      when: nginxconf_changed.changed
‚ö†Ô∏è Note about the regex
This will comment out a server block if it finds one in nginx.conf.
If you have multiple server blocks in nginx.conf (unusual), we can tighten the regex to match specifically the one with server_name _; and root /usr/share/nginx/html;.

If you want the ‚Äúexact-match‚Äù version, use this instead:

regexp: 'server\s*\{[\s\S]*?server_name\s+_;\s*[\s\S]*?root\s+\/usr\/share\/nginx\/html;[\s\S]*?\}'
Add it to your runner
If you‚Äôre running them in order, run:

ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini 11-nginx-default-server-fix.yml
Or if you have a site.yml orchestrator, include it after 03-nginx.yml and before any certbot steps.

What we‚Äôre going to do in 03-nginx.yml
Remove/disable any ‚Äúdefault‚Äù site file that sets default_server or returns weird codes.

Ensure nginx.conf does NOT contain an embedded default server {} block (Amazon Linux / some builds ship one).

Keep your real vhost in /etc/nginx/conf.d/motorcade.conf as the only effective server for the domain.

nginx -t then reload.

Add this block near the end of 03-nginx.yml
Place it after you install nginx and after you template/copy motorcade.conf, and before the final nginx reload (or this can do the reload itself).

Adjust paths only if your distro differs ‚Äî but your screenshots show /etc/nginx/conf.d/*.conf.

# --- Prevent nginx default vhost from hijacking requests ----------------------

- name: Find common default nginx vhost files that may conflict
  become: true
  ansible.builtin.stat:
    path: "{{ item }}"
  register: nginx_default_vhost_stats
  loop:
    - /etc/nginx/conf.d/default.conf
    - /etc/nginx/conf.d/00-default.conf
    - /etc/nginx/default.d/default.conf
    - /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/default
    - /etc/nginx/sites-available/default

- name: Disable conflicting default vhost files (rename to .disabled)
  become: true
  ansible.builtin.command: >
    mv "{{ item.stat.path }}" "{{ item.stat.path }}.disabled"
  args:
    creates: "{{ item.stat.path }}.disabled"
  when: item.stat.exists
  loop: "{{ nginx_default_vhost_stats.results }}"

- name: Remove any embedded default server block from /etc/nginx/nginx.conf (if present)
  become: true
  ansible.builtin.replace:
    path: /etc/nginx/nginx.conf
    regexp: '(?s)^\s*server\s*\{.*?#\s*Settings\s*for\s*a\s*TLS\s*enabled\s*server\.\s*\n.*?\}\s*\n'
    replace: ''
  notify: Reload nginx
  # If the regex doesn't match, replace does nothing (safe).

- name: Ensure nginx.conf does NOT contain a non-commented default server { } block on port 80
  become: true
  ansible.builtin.lineinfile:
    path: /etc/nginx/nginx.conf
    regexp: '^\s*server\s*\{'
    state: absent
  notify: Reload nginx
  # NOTE: This is intentionally conservative; if you keep other server blocks in nginx.conf,
  # remove this task and rely on the replace task above instead.

- name: Validate nginx configuration
  become: true
  ansible.builtin.command: nginx -t
  changed_when: false

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Add/confirm a handler in the same playbook

handlers:
  - name: Reload nginx
    become: true
    ansible.builtin.service:
      name: nginx
      state: reloaded
Important note (based on your screenshots)
You had an nginx.conf that included a built-in default server { listen 80; root /usr/share/nginx/html; ... } and also had /etc/nginx/conf.d/00-default.conf returning 444.

STEP 2 ‚Äî ADD THIS BLOCK DIRECTLY AFTER IT

- name: Disable any remaining default nginx site files
  become: true
  ansible.builtin.shell: |
    for f in \
      /etc/nginx/conf.d/00-default.conf \
      /etc/nginx/conf.d/default.conf \
      /etc/nginx/default.d/default.conf \
      /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/default \
      /etc/nginx/sites-available/default; do
        if [ -f "$f" ]; then
          mv "$f" "$f.disabled"
        fi
    done
  args:
    warn: false
üëâ This safely renames, not deletes. Recovery is easy.

STEP 3 ‚Äî ADD THIS BLOCK (very important)
This removes the embedded default server block that Amazon Linux sometimes ships inside nginx.conf.

Add below Step 2:

- name: Remove embedded default server block from nginx.conf if present
  become: true
  ansible.builtin.replace:
    path: /etc/nginx/nginx.conf
    regexp: '(?s)\n\s*server\s*\{\s*listen\s+80;.*?\n\s*\}'
    replace: ''
This:

Only removes a server { listen 80; ... }

Leaves your global nginx config intact

Does nothing if it‚Äôs already clean

ChatGPT said:
I‚Äôll clean up your Nginx playbook YAML to be fully valid, idempotent, and aligned with what you actually have on Amazon Linux 2023 (including the right default config handling).

Here‚Äôs a fixed, valid, idempotent version of your Nginx YAML. It also fixes the two big gotchas in your current file:

server_name: _ can trigger ‚Äúconflicting server name '_'‚Äù warnings depending on what else exists. Better: set it to your real domains (or omit entirely and rely on default_server in a dedicated default block).

On Amazon Linux, the default server block is often not /etc/nginx/conf.d/default.conf. You previously had /etc/nginx/conf.d/00-default.conf. So we remove/disable both safely.

---
- name: Motorcade ‚Äì configure Nginx
  hosts: motorcade
  become: true

  vars:
    web_root: /var/www/motorcade
    # Put your real domains here (recommended)
    server_names:
      - motorcade.vip
      - www.motorcade.vip

  tasks:
    - name: Ensure nginx is installed
      ansible.builtin.package:
        name: nginx
        state: present

    - name: Create web root
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: "{{ web_root }}"
        state: directory
        owner: nginx
        group: nginx
        mode: "0755"

    - name: Create nginx server block
      ansible.builtin.copy:
        dest: /etc/nginx/conf.d/motorcade.conf
        owner: root
        group: root
        mode: "0644"
        content: |
          server {
              listen 80;
              server_name {{ server_names | join(' ') }};
              root {{ web_root }};
              index index.php index.html;

              location / {
                  try_files $uri $uri/ /index.php?$args;
              }

              location ~ \.php$ {
                  include fastcgi_params;
                  fastcgi_pass unix:/run/php-fpm/www.sock;
                  fastcgi_index index.php;
                  fastcgi_param SCRIPT_FILENAME $document_root$fastcgi_script_name;
              }
          }

    # Remove common default configs (Amazon Linux / RHEL variants differ)
    - name: Remove default nginx configs if present
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: "{{ item }}"
        state: absent
      loop:
        - /etc/nginx/conf.d/default.conf
        - /etc/nginx/conf.d/00-default.conf

    - name: Test nginx configuration
      ansible.builtin.command: nginx -t
      register: nginx_test
      changed_when: false

    - name: Ensure nginx is enabled and running
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: nginx
        state: started
        enabled: true

    - name: Reload nginx (only if config test passed)
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: nginx
        state: reloaded
      when: nginx_test.rc == 0
Notes on what I fixed/improved
‚úÖ YAML is clean/valid

‚úÖ Uses server_names list ‚Üí generates motorcade.vip www.motorcade.vip

‚úÖ try_files now falls back to WordPress correctly: /index.php?$args

‚úÖ Removes both likely default config filenames

‚úÖ Adds nginx install + enable/start (safe/idempotent)

‚úÖ Keeps nginx -t check

If you want, paste your playbook 11 (SSL) and I‚Äôll fix that one too so it‚Äôs the same quality and won‚Äôt break reruns.

Yep ‚Äî and the browser error matters: ‚Äúrefused to connect‚Äù = the TCP connection to port 80 is being refused (not DNS). That usually means nothing is listening on 80 or a firewall is rejecting it.

Good news: this is almost always a quick fix.

1) Confirm what‚Äôs actually listening on 80 (on the EC2 box)
SSH into the instance and run:

sudo ss -lntp | egrep ':80|:443' || true
sudo systemctl status nginx --no-pager
sudo nginx -t
If nginx is NOT running, start it:
sudo systemctl restart nginx
sudo systemctl enable nginx
Then test from the server itself (this bypasses DNS and the internet):

curl -I http://127.0.0.1/
curl -I http://localhost/
curl -I http://$(curl -s http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/public-ipv4)/
If 127.0.0.1 works but public IP fails ‚Üí firewall / security group / NACL

If 127.0.0.1 fails ‚Üí nginx config or service problem

2) The most likely cause: the server_name _ in your playbook
Your playbook has:

server_name: _
In nginx, _ is not a magic wildcard. If your old config was working and you replaced it with a server block that doesn‚Äôt match the request Host header the way you expect, behavior can get weird.

Fix now: change it to the real domain(s).

Update 03-nginx.yml vars to:
vars:
  web_root: /var/www/motorcade
  server_name: "motorcade.vip www.motorcade.vip"
Then run the playbook again:

ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini 03-nginx.yml
3) Second likely cause: you removed the default config but nginx is now broken
Your task removes:

path: /etc/nginx/conf.d/default.conf
state: absent
On Amazon Linux nginx often uses /etc/nginx/default.d/*.conf or a packaged default server. Removing one file usually is fine, BUT if your server block didn‚Äôt load (or got written wrong), nginx might end up with nothing valid for :80.

Quick ‚Äúget it back online‚Äù rollback (safe)
On the instance:

sudo ls -la /etc/nginx/conf.d/
sudo cat /etc/nginx/conf.d/motorcade.conf
sudo nginx -t
If nginx -t fails, do this fast restore:

sudo mv /etc/nginx/conf.d/motorcade.conf /etc/nginx/conf.d/motorcade.conf.bad.$(date +%s)
sudo systemctl restart nginx
That puts you back to whatever other config exists.

4) One more thing: your PHP location block is missing fastcgi_param include ordering
Not usually a ‚Äúrefused connection‚Äù cause, but to be safe your PHP block should be the common working one:

location ~ \.php$ {
    include fastcgi.conf;
    fastcgi_pass unix:/run/php-fpm/www.sock;
}
fastcgi.conf already includes the correct SCRIPT_FILENAME mapping on many distros.

5) Make sure it‚Äôs not AWS blocking it
Even if nginx is perfect, AWS can still block port 80.

Check on AWS side:

Security Group inbound must allow TCP 80 from 0.0.0.0/0

NACL must allow inbound/outbound 80

Instance has a public IP and you‚Äôre hitting the right one

From your earlier screenshot, SG inbound had 22/80/443 open ‚Äî so probably OK.

Do this in order (fast recovery checklist)
Run these and paste the outputs (even screenshots are fine):

sudo ss -lntp | egrep ':80|:443' || true
sudo systemctl status nginx --no-pager
sudo nginx -t
sudo cat /etc/nginx/conf.d/motorcade.conf
Once I see those 3 outputs, I can tell you exactly why it‚Äôs refusing connections and the shortest fix.

Very likely fix (you can do immediately)
Change:

server_name: _
to:

server_name: "motorcade.vip www.motorcade.vip"
rerun 03-nginx.yml, then:

sudo systemctl restart nginx
That alone may bring it right back.

Why your YAML originally caused trouble
There were two real issues, both subtle:

Issue 1: server_names vs server_name
You correctly changed to a list:

  - motorcade.vip
  - www.motorcade.vip
But Nginx expects one line:

server_name motorcade.vip www.motorcade.vip;
You fixed this correctly later with:

server_name {{ server_names | join(' ') }};
üëç That part is now right.

Issue 2 (the dangerous one): removing configs without a fallback
This task is risky:

- name: Remove default nginx configs if present
  file:
    path: /etc/nginx/conf.d/default.conf
    state: absent
Because if your custom config is ever removed or renamed, Nginx has nothing left.

That‚Äôs exactly what happened during debugging.

The safe, corrected 03-nginx.yml (USE THIS)
This version:

Never leaves Nginx without a server

Supports WordPress correctly

Is safe to rerun

Won‚Äôt break production

‚úÖ Final 03-nginx.yml
---
- name: Motorcade ‚Äì configure Nginx
  hosts: motorcade
  become: true

  vars:
    web_root: /var/www/motorcade
    server_names:
      - motorcade.vip
      - www.motorcade.vip

  tasks:
    - name: Ensure nginx is installed
      ansible.builtin.package:
        name: nginx
        state: present

    - name: Ensure nginx is enabled and running
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: nginx
        state: started
        enabled: true

    - name: Create web root
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: "{{ web_root }}"
        state: directory
        owner: nginx
        group: nginx
        mode: "0755"

    - name: Install motorcade nginx server block
      ansible.builtin.copy:
        dest: /etc/nginx/conf.d/motorcade.conf
        owner: root
        group: root
        mode: "0644"
        content: |
          server {
              listen 80;
              server_name {{ server_names | join(' ') }};
              root {{ web_root }};
              index index.php index.html;

              location / {
                  try_files $uri $uri/ /index.php?$args;
              }

              location ~ \.php$ {
                  include fastcgi.conf;
                  fastcgi_pass unix:/run/php-fpm/www.sock;
              }
          }

    - name: Disable default nginx config if present (safe)
      ansible.builtin.command: mv /etc/nginx/conf.d/default.conf /etc/nginx/conf.d/default.conf.disabled
      args:
        removes: /etc/nginx/conf.d/default.conf
      notify: reload nginx

    - name: Test nginx configuration
      ansible.builtin.command: nginx -t
      changed_when: false

  handlers:
    - name: reload nginx
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: nginx
        state: reloaded
Why this version is safe
‚úî Never deletes configs blindly
‚úî Always installs a valid server block first
‚úî Uses fastcgi.conf (correct for Amazon Linux)
‚úî WordPress-friendly try_files
‚úî Idempotent (safe to rerun)

ChatGPT said:
I‚Äôm going to fix your 11-nginx-ssl.yml so it matches Option B (webroot, no nginx plugin) and won‚Äôt auto-edit your Nginx config; then I‚Äôll give you the exact run command + a quick verification checklist.

Perfect ‚Äî your current 11-nginx-ssl.yml is NOT Option B right now.

It‚Äôs using:

certbot --nginx ...
That is the nginx plugin, and it can rewrite configs (which is what we wanted to avoid).

Below is a clean, safe Option B playbook:

Uses webroot validation

Does not let certbot touch nginx config

Creates a dedicated ACME challenge location

Adds a separate 443 server block using the cert files

Adds HTTP ‚Üí HTTPS redirect

Includes nginx -t guardrails so reload only happens if valid

‚úÖ Replace your 11-nginx-ssl.yml with this (Option B: webroot)
---
- name: Motorcade - SSL (Let's Encrypt) via webroot (Option B)
  hosts: motorcade
  become: true

  vars:
    domain_primary: motorcade.vip
    domain_aliases:
      - www.motorcade.vip

    web_root: /var/www/motorcade
    acme_root: /var/www/letsencrypt

    nginx_http_conf: /etc/nginx/conf.d/motorcade.conf
    nginx_ssl_conf: /etc/nginx/conf.d/motorcade-ssl.conf

    # change if you want
    le_email: patrick@motorcade.vip

  tasks:
    - name: Install certbot (and helpers)
      ansible.builtin.package:
        name:
          - certbot
          - python3-certbot-nginx
        state: present

    - name: Ensure nginx is enabled and running
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: nginx
        state: started
        enabled: true

    - name: Create ACME webroot directory
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: "{{ acme_root }}"
        state: directory
        owner: nginx
        group: nginx
        mode: "0755"

    # --- HTTP vhost: serve WordPress + ACME challenge ---
    - name: Install HTTP vhost with ACME challenge location
      ansible.builtin.copy:
        dest: "{{ nginx_http_conf }}"
        owner: root
        group: root
        mode: "0644"
        content: |
          server {
              listen 80;
              server_name {{ domain_primary }}{% for d in domain_aliases %} {{ d }}{% endfor %};

              # ACME challenge (Let's Encrypt)
              location ^~ /.well-known/acme-challenge/ {
                  root {{ acme_root }};
                  default_type "text/plain";
                  try_files $uri =404;
              }

              root {{ web_root }};
              index index.php index.html;

              location / {
                  try_files $uri $uri/ /index.php?$args;
              }

              location ~ \.php$ {
                  include fastcgi_params;
                  fastcgi_pass unix:/run/php-fpm/www.sock;
                  fastcgi_index index.php;
                  fastcgi_param SCRIPT_FILENAME $document_root$fastcgi_script_name;
              }
          }

    - name: Test nginx configuration (pre-cert)
      ansible.builtin.command: nginx -t
      changed_when: false

    - name: Reload nginx (pre-cert)
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: nginx
        state: reloaded

    # --- Obtain certificate (webroot) ---
    - name: Obtain/renew Let's Encrypt cert (webroot, non-interactive)
      ansible.builtin.command: >
        certbot certonly --webroot
        -w {{ acme_root }}
        -d {{ domain_primary }}
        {% for d in domain_aliases %}-d {{ d }} {% endfor %}
        --agree-tos --non-interactive
        -m {{ le_email }}
      register: certbot_out
      changed_when: "'Congratulations' in certbot_out.stdout or 'successfully' in certbot_out.stdout|lower"
      failed_when: certbot_out.rc != 0

    # --- HTTPS vhost: dedicated 443 block + redirect ---
    - name: Install HTTPS vhost (443) using issued cert
      ansible.builtin.copy:
        dest: "{{ nginx_ssl_conf }}"
        owner: root
        group: root
        mode: "0644"
        content: |
          server {
              listen 443 ssl http2;
              server_name {{ domain_primary }}{% for d in domain_aliases %} {{ d }}{% endfor %};

              ssl_certificate     /etc/letsencrypt/live/{{ domain_primary }}/fullchain.pem;
              ssl_certificate_key /etc/letsencrypt/live/{{ domain_primary }}/privkey.pem;

              # recommended baseline
              ssl_session_cache shared:SSL:10m;
              ssl_session_timeout 10m;
              ssl_protocols TLSv1.2 TLSv1.3;

              root {{ web_root }};
              index index.php index.html;

              location / {
                  try_files $uri $uri/ /index.php?$args;
              }

              location ~ \.php$ {
                  include fastcgi_params;
                  fastcgi_pass unix:/run/php-fpm/www.sock;
                  fastcgi_index index.php;
                  fastcgi_param SCRIPT_FILENAME $document_root$fastcgi_script_name;
              }
          }

          # redirect HTTP -> HTTPS
          server {
              listen 80;
              server_name {{ domain_primary }}{% for d in domain_aliases %} {{ d }}{% endfor %};
              return 301 https://$host$request_uri;
          }

    - name: Test nginx configuration (post-cert)
      ansible.builtin.command: nginx -t
      changed_when: false

    - name: Reload nginx (post-cert)
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: nginx
        state: reloaded

    # --- quick visibility checks ---
    - name: Show listening ports (80/443)
      ansible.builtin.shell: ss -lntp | egrep ':(80|443)\b' || true
      register: listen_ports
      changed_when: false

    - name: Print listening ports
      ansible.builtin.debug:
        var: listen_ports.stdout_lines
Run it
ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini 11-nginx-ssl.yml
Do NOT use --ask-vault-pass unless you actually encrypted vars with vault (that ‚ÄúAttempting to decrypt‚Ä¶‚Äù message was coming from that).

Then from your laptop:

Take a breath ‚Äî this is a very common step on fresh server installs.

What‚Äôs happening (plain English)
WordPress is asking for FTP credentials because:

It cannot write to /wp-content/themes directly

So it falls back to ‚ÄúFTP mode‚Äù as a safety mechanism

On modern VPS installs (like yours with Ansible + nginx + PHP-FPM), we do NOT use FTP at all.

We fix this once, properly.

Correct Fix (Best Practice ‚Äì do this)
1Ô∏è‚É£ Fix ownership of WordPress files (server-side)
SSH into the server and run:

sudo chown -R nginx:nginx /var/www/motorcade
sudo find /var/www/motorcade -type d -exec chmod 755 {} \;
sudo find /var/www/motorcade -type f -exec chmod 644 {} \;
This ensures:

nginx (and PHP-FPM) can write files

WordPress no longer needs FTP

2Ô∏è‚É£ Force WordPress to use direct filesystem access
Edit wp-config.php:

sudo nano /var/www/motorcade/wp-config.php
Add above /* That's all, stop editing! */:

define('FS_METHOD', 'direct');
Save and exit.

This explicitly tells WordPress:

‚ÄúYou are allowed to write files directly. Do NOT ask for FTP.‚Äù

3Ô∏è‚É£ Reload services (safe)
sudo systemctl reload php-fpm
sudo systemctl reload nginx
Now try again

Below is a clean, safe, idempotent Ansible playbook you can save as 12-wp-filesystem.yml.
It does only what we just fixed manually ‚Äî nothing risky.

‚úÖ 12-wp-filesystem.yml
Purpose:

Fix WordPress ownership & permissions

Force FS_METHOD=direct

Reload services safely

üìÑ Playbook: 12-wp-filesystem.yml
---
- name: Motorcade ‚Äì WordPress filesystem permissions & direct FS method
  hosts: motorcade
  become: true

  vars:
    web_root: /var/www/motorcade
    wp_config: /var/www/motorcade/wp-config.php
    web_user: nginx
    web_group: nginx

  tasks:
    - name: Ensure correct ownership for WordPress files
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: "{{ web_root }}"
        owner: "{{ web_user }}"
        group: "{{ web_group }}"
        recurse: true

    - name: Ensure directory permissions (755)
      ansible.builtin.command: >
        find {{ web_root }} -type d -exec chmod 755 {} \;
      changed_when: false

    - name: Ensure file permissions (644)
      ansible.builtin.command: >
        find {{ web_root }} -type f -exec chmod 644 {} \;
      changed_when: false

    - name: Ensure FS_METHOD is set to direct in wp-config.php
      ansible.builtin.lineinfile:
        path: "{{ wp_config }}"
        line: "define('FS_METHOD', 'direct');"
        insertafter: "^define\\('DB_COLLATE'"
        state: present

    - name: Reload PHP-FPM
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: php-fpm
        state: reloaded

    - name: Reload nginx
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: nginx
        state: reloaded
‚ñ∂Ô∏è How to run it
From your Ansible directory:

ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini 12-wp-filesystem.yml --ask-vault-pass
(or omit --ask-vault-pass if this playbook doesn‚Äôt use vault vars)

‚úÖ Safe for production

‚úÖ Fully repeatable (reinstall-safe)

What that error actually means (plain English)

‚úÖ Playbook 12 ‚Äî WordPress Uploads & Filesystem (FINAL)
Create this file:

nano 12-wp-filesystem.yml
Paste exactly this:

---
- name: Motorcade ‚Äì WordPress filesystem permissions & uploads
  hosts: motorcade
  become: true

  vars:
    wp_root: /var/www/motorcade
    wp_user: nginx
    wp_group: nginx

  tasks:
    - name: Ensure wp-content exists
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: "{{ wp_root }}/wp-content"
        state: directory
        owner: "{{ wp_user }}"
        group: "{{ wp_group }}"
        mode: "0755"

    - name: Ensure uploads directory exists
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: "{{ wp_root }}/wp-content/uploads"
        state: directory
        owner: "{{ wp_user }}"
        group: "{{ wp_group }}"
        mode: "0755"
        recurse: yes

    - name: Ensure correct ownership for all WordPress files
      ansible.builtin.file:
        path: "{{ wp_root }}"
        owner: "{{ wp_user }}"
        group: "{{ wp_group }}"
        recurse: yes

    - name: Ensure directory permissions (755)
      ansible.builtin.command: >
        find {{ wp_root }} -type d -exec chmod 755 {} \;
      changed_when: false

    - name: Ensure file permissions (644)
      ansible.builtin.command: >
        find {{ wp_root }} -type f -exec chmod 644 {} \;
      changed_when: false

    - name: Ensure FS_METHOD is set to direct in wp-config.php
      ansible.builtin.lineinfile:
        path: "{{ wp_root }}/wp-config.php"
        line: "define('FS_METHOD', 'direct');"
        insertbefore: "/* That's all, stop editing! */"
        state: present

    - name: Reload PHP-FPM
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: php-fpm
        state: reloaded

    - name: Reload nginx
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: nginx
        state: reloaded

ansible-playbook -i inventory.ini 12-wp-filesystem.yml --ask-vault-pass

No files are removed. No content is touched.

2. It does NOT replace wp-config.php
This task is the key one you‚Äôre worried about:

ansible.builtin.lineinfile:
  path: "{{ wp_config }}"
  line: "define('FS_METHOD', 'direct');"
lineinfile behavior:

‚úÖ If the line already exists ‚Üí leave it alone

‚úÖ If the line does not exist ‚Üí add exactly one line

‚ùå It does not rewrite the file

‚ùå It does not reorder content

‚ùå It does not remove anything

So your existing:

DB credentials

salts

keys

custom settings

are completely untouched.

3. Permissions changes are safe and intentional
These two commands:

find /var/www/motorcade -type d -exec chmod 755 {} \;
find /var/www/motorcade -type f -exec chmod 644 {} \;
Do exactly what WordPress expects:

Directories ‚Üí executable (enterable)

Files ‚Üí readable by PHP, not writable by random users

This is best practice, not risky.

4. It does not restart services
state: reloaded
Reload = re-read config
Restart = kill + start (we do not do that)

So:

No dropped connections

No PHP crashes

No downtime

What would replace a file (and we are NOT doing)
Action	Risk
copy: with full file	‚ö†Ô∏è overwrites
template: without backup	‚ö†Ô∏è overwrites
rm -rf	üíÄ
Manual nano save	human error
You are doing none of those.

‚úÖ This playbook is idempotent
‚úÖ It is safe to run multiple times
‚úÖ It is production-grade
